comments.text:
+Yaakov Hatanian Nope you are incorrect There isn't a PHD in Medicine
A PHD is a doctorate in any discipline except medicine, or sometimes 
theology.
The highest degree is the Ph.D which is a degree ini the educational field. 
Then there is a degree in the medical field for doctors, dentists, etc. and 
those are called M.D. For a lawyer, the title is J.D. It goes on from 
there. Now an MBA is a Masters in Business Administration. CPA is a 
Certified Public Accountant. The top degrees are the M.D. and J.D. 
designations. The Ph.D. comes in next as it is the top educational degree. 
The Master's Degree, the Bachelor's Degree, the Associate's Degree and 
various certifications go back down the ladder. In other words, the M.D., 
J.D., Ph.D. are the top of the degree ladder.

them: Black Holes. What's more, based on mathematical projections, we know 
that at the heart of every black hole lies... a Quantum Singularity!

the center of black holes: Put the two together and you've got the basis of 
Multiverse Theory - which by the way, is accepted by a growing number of 
physicists. It's speculative of course, but IS actually supported by some 
evidence... Unlike creationism, which is built on preconceptions and weak 
inferences based on scientific hindsight.

comments.text:
+rationalmartian I don't think you understand it that well, because people 
who truly study it, as in mathematicians don't understand it as much as you 
think. It's a very mysterious and murky subject. All you said above is 
true, COBE probe found the background radiation. The cosmological constant 
you mentioned is not really relevant, and I'm not sure you even understand 
why Einstein called it his biggest blunder. It's a constant that was needed 
to get the space-time field equations to work, without it they simply 
degenerated. It's a constant that can't really be explained even to this 
day, and what makes it even more perplexing is that there is now a proved 
acceleration that's happening not just a standard linear expansion. We have 
"theories" to suggest as to why but all of them involve the dark forces 
which in themselves are not even close to being understood. But we're 
jumping ahead of ourselves, I'm not exactly sure why you brought up 
expansion, I'm talking about the actual big bang and the mystery behind it. 
If you really did know it well then you'd know that Big Bang is split up 
into eras, the first 3 or 4 eras we know almost nothing about because the 
temperature at the end of 4th one is 100 mill hotter then the surface of 
the sun not allowing us to get anywhere close to experimenting with in any 
predictable future. Even the newer eras are very murky, maybe at 
nucleosyntheis we can use some high-energy quantum mechanical model to 
slighly approximate the behaviour of space-time and energies at those 
temperatures, still very speculative. So as to the actual big bang, it's 
extremely mysterious, the first GUT era, which is named after the Grand 
Unified Theory states there was one single force, the temperatures at that 
level is nothing that we will EVER be able to reach and even if we ever had 
reached it we wouldnt be able to study anything since all the normal laws 
break far below those "unification" energies. Don't get me wrong I'm not 
saying it's an invalid theory, like you said the evidences that we have 
support the Big Bang, but do you not see how it's almost god like in a way 
if you read Genesis and compare the 2 it's almost indistinguishable. It 
basically means that all the forces of the universe, the forces that hold 
matter together the forces that hold gluons and leptons together is in face 
one singe energy. That's what I meant when I said it has a religious 
overtone, not that the whole theory is wrong, it probably is very accurate, 
but even being accurate it's still a mystery.
comments.author: VanillaSnake21

comments.text:
Sorry but it just isn't. It is a well rounded theory with plenty of real 
evidence. It is absolutely the best explanation for what we observe. Have 
you any familiarity with it attention all???
Einstein's theory of relativity predicted an expanding/contracting 
universe. But at the time it was thought the universe was stable. So 
Einstein invented the cosmological constant to bring it inline. Einstein 
later said that this "was the biggest mistake of his career".
Some years later Edwin Hubble discoverd that the universe was indeed 
expanding by observation. Theoretical physicists/cosmologists got to work 
and predicted that there should be an "echo" left over that should be still 
observable, working out roughly what it should be like temp, frequency etc. 
It turns out that is exactly what we do find as the microwave background 
radiation.
Anyone doing even a small amount of research into the subject HONESTLY can 
really come to no other reasonable conclusion. It is only the religious 
with an agenda who missinterpret things and downright lie. This is the 
reason for the "religious debate". This is the only controversy.
Pretty much every physicists and cosmologist accepts it as the best 
explanation for what we observe with only a few mavericks/cranks seeing 
things differently.
BTW how do you conclude that "it's one of those things that will never be 
truly understood". Seems I understand it slightly better than you do, yet I 
would never have the confidence to make such a statement. Seems a little 
conceited. Don't you think we should leave questions like this to those who 
ACTUALLY really DO understand about this and work in the field.
comments.author: rationalmartian

comments.text:
There are differences between socialism and communism (
http://www.diffen.com/difference/Communism_vs_Socialism).

I haven't seen anyone on either side of the U.S. fence advocating for 
nationalizing major industries or making cooperatives of them.  

You have asserted that the military and penal systems are in line with 
capitalism?  How so?  Wouldn't it be more true to say the military should 
be privatized completely and only those who can afford to pay should be 
afforded protection?

I would argue instead that taxation for the purposes maintaining the state 
(government, military, penal, regulatory, etc) is a form of socialist 
construct that all sides agree is necessary to some extent (exactly to what 
extent is really the source of division).

Certainly the offshoots of the military, that being the "industrial 
complex" part of it is capitalistic as is the penal system in large part 
(which is a serious problem).

Your proposed solution to oligarchies is incorrect.  That may be a solution 
to corporations getting too large... but it doesn't prevent any individual 
or family from growing.  Worse yet, when all political contribution limits 
have been removed (which becoming more and more the case), the opportunity 
for the uber-privileged to purchase politicians (and laws) that benefit 
them more than anyone, class mobility suffers.  

I want to note here that I'm not against success (that is the reason for 
being and entrepreneur), only that when 85 people on the planet have more 
wealth than the bottom 3.5 billion, there's an issue.

Healthcare has been privatized for the entire existence of the U.S. (with 
perhaps the exception of the V.A. hospitals which can be considered 
stepchild of the military).  Medicaid and Medicare pay for some of it... 
but it is paid to private firms and individuals, not government firms.

Studies of other first-world countries show that their costs are lower 
because the ENTIRE COUNTRY negotiates with medical and pharmaceutical 
providers to get the lowest price.  The highly fragmented (state by state 
and municipality by municipality) method in the U.S. is part of the reason 
costs are so artificially high.

Each and every administration since the Vietnam war has increased the debt. 
 Prior to that there was an increase for each war and then a period of 
pay-down.  All administrations are to blame (left and right).  The 
republicans certainly have no legitimate claim to reducing debt or deficit 
(I'm not saying the democrats do either).

I doubt anyone would argue that the current S.S. program is sustainable. 
 In contrast however, I'd point out that the vast majority of people 
couldn't invest their way out of a wet paper bag and most are just as 
likely to lose whatever they have in the next Bernie Madoff scandal.  Less 
likely if what you mean is more like "investing in a mutual fund".

I'm a believer in "incentive based everything".  But I wouldn't go so far 
as to say that all social programs create a disincentive for people to 
work.  I believe in limited social nets.  Your likely too young to see how 
things beyond your control (like a car accident) can suddenly destroy 
everything.  There are some pretty sneaky ways that the medical 
establishment can jack your costs into the hundreds of thousands in days or 
weeks despite insurance and you're suddenly destitute and need a hand up.

I own a business and work with multi-billion-dollar manufacturers for a 
living (and for the last 20 years).  I'm not unaware of business and 
government at a very large scale.  There are companies out there that own 
3500 hospitals under 20 different company names.  You'd be amazed at how 
billions can be skimmed from the government (and taxpayers) as well as 
private individuals.  One of the contributors is the grand network of 
insurance providers.

You see MUCH lower costs in single-payer countries.  It doesn't fix 
everything... but it does limit some of the massive loopholes that exist 
because of byzantine rules for hundreds of insurance providers and 
variations from state to state.

And... both the left and right sides of any country that has single-payer 
want to keep it once they see the benefits.

There is so much nearly-religious but low-knowledge fervor around the 
subject in the U.S.

But then, that applies to much of the electorate about most topics.  Which 
is why it's not a democracy but a democratic republic.

Enough babble... I have to get my taxes in before the deadline.  

Perhaps we'll solve the world's problems another day.
comments.author: parkjammer

comments.text:
+parkjammer  I am the same, an issue based independant.

--------------------------------------------------

(1) What is socialism by your definition? Socialism is government hand outs 
and the opposition to private ownership of production

(2) Is it different from a "social program" A social program is a form of 
socialism and hurts everyone involved in the long term fundamentally.

(3) What is better... an ideology... or survival? I'm not sure what you're 
getting at with this one, but I'd choose both: the ideology of survival.

--------------------------------------------------

Actually that's communism. Socialism is the community ownership of business 
among other things like government controlling private wealth.

Means of transportation, jailing(i.e the court system), and education are 
very much in line with capitalism. Health Care however should be 
privatized. Programs like SS and medicaid/care are socialist and hurt the 
country and those who receive the benefits.

comments.text:
I'm an issue-based person (neither right nor left).  I'm also a software 
engineer and try to think rationally about things.  I have a couple of 
questions for you:

--------------------------------------------------

(1) What is socialism by your definition?

(2) Is it different from a "social program"

(3) What is better... an ideology... or survival?

--------------------------------------------------

In a truly socialist country the government owns the means of production. 
 There are no private businesses.  Has there ever been any move to own the 
means of production in the U.S. by any major party?  I think not.

Is pooling your resource "socialist"?  If so, then these are all socialist 
constructs that everyone (including the majority of right-leaning U.S. 
people) believe in:

- the military-industrial complex (massive pooled resources ostensibly for 
the protection of all)

- the prison-industrial complex (as above)
- the highway system
- several rail systems
- medicare/medicaid
- most of the school system

In this past issue of Scientific American a group of MIT PhDs showed that 
there is a formula that can be applied to civilizations that matches known 
history (known civilizations).  They found that there were three ways a 
civilization died:

(1) natural disaster (e.g., volcano, disease, etc)

(2) destruction of resources

and interestingly

(3) income inequality (results in revolution or takeover by another 
civilization through war)

I'm a software engineer and an entrepreneur.  I seek accomplishment and 
wealth and don't begrudge most who achieve it.  Even so, I'm not a 
proponent of having a few multi-billionaire oligarchs running everything 
around the world.  Do I have a solution or any power to implement one if I 
did?  No.  Even so I would advocate for a mechanism to reduce income 
inequality.  Those who do not understand the terms involved and think 
simply would cry "wealth redistribution, socialism, communism" and such... 
and they would be wrong.

The U.S. is in decline on several fronts, not least of which is debt and 
income inequality.  It is bound to wind up in collapse or revolution at 
some point unless improvements can be made.

It is silly to label socialism as the basis for ruining the country when 
(A) the country and its parties are not socialist and (B) the debt and 
inequality are created as much or more by the right.

Something to consider.

comments.text:
The Genesis account is referenced by God the Father and the Son, the 
prophets, etc.

This is an invalid argument. I said that the stories of Adam & Eve and Noah 
and the Ark may come from a previous outside account separate from the rest 
of the Torah. Moses and Abraham are some of the earliest first-person 
accounts and everything else in Genesis is likely metaphorical (Jesus used 
quite a lot of metaphor in his teachings). I noted similarities to the saga 
of Gilgamesh. Your point is simply that once this account was included, 
other prophets sited it. That doesn't argue against my point. Saying that 
Jesus quoted from Genesis doesn't add validity to the story, it just means 
that as a rabbi, Jesus learned the story and preached a sermon. And you 
could argue that as the Messiah, what he said is the word of God, and 
you're entitled to make that argument, but my interpretation is that Jesus 
was reaching out to the Jewish community at the time and even then his 
teachings upset the pharocies because the thing Jesus said in his mission 
WAVERED FROM THE ACCEPTED DOGMA OF THE AGE. Jesus never said anything about 
atoms and radio waves, but we don't refute their existence. God is 
supposedly a being of infinite knowledge and wisdom, and I take the 
position that Jesus chose not to explain things that we as humans would be 
unable to understand. As the son of God, I think Jesus could have told 
people about airplanes and cell phones, but knowing people would think him 
a madman, Jesus said nothing of it. Does that mean Christ could not foresee 
their existence? No one alive then would be at all affected by that 
information, and I feel it is the same with this issue. 

---

Also Moses gave us the Genesis account, not Abraham. 

Yes, let's site the guy who was raised Egyptian in a polytheistic society 
as the true prophet for origin of Genesis. That really doesn't contradict 
my point either.

---

Just disagree with the Bible, don't make God's word read what it clearly 
doesn't.

You realize, I hope, that this statement is entirely the basis for the 
myriad of Christian denominations. How would there be Catholicism, 
Lutheranism, Presbyterianism, Methodism, etc, if the Bible was not open to 
various schools of interpretation?

---

Do you have evidence that substantiates your claim of content being omitted 
during transcription?

One of my favorite examples is with the concept of hell versus Gahenna. In 
many English translations, Gahenna is equated with hell, but contextually, 
Gahenna was an actual place at the time of Christ. I've read various 
accounts of Gahenna being a place where sacrifices were performed and as 
such the Israelites believed it to be cursed and also i've heard it 
described as a place in the Valley of Hinnom where they burned cadavers and 
refuse. The point is that these are two very different concepts, hell being 
a metaphysical afterlife while Gahenna is simply a place where things are 
thrown away.

There is the line in the Bible that "one shalt not suffer a witch to live" 
but Solomon summons the Witch of Endor, which implies that the council he 
gains from the witch, as well as the means of summoning the witch, were 
deemed permissible in the tenants of the time. In the original document in 
its original language, distinctions were made between orders that used 
magic for evil. This comes up in documents regarding the Salem Witch Trials.

---

It has to do with how you practice your faith, not like a hypocrite who 
wants attention from men only but as one essentially after God's own heart.﻿

The point of Matthew 6 is that you are expected to conduct your religion to 
further your own relationship with God, not to draw attention. The problem 
non-Christians have with Creationists is that they constantly demanded to 
be accommodated. It is not the purview of public education to cater to 
various religious institutions, and whether or not it conflicts with your 
religion, the theory of evolution has testable merits and demonstrative 
evidence and is the accepted theory for the diversity of life. No one knows 
how life STARTED on the planet. If you are Christian and you don't agree 
with evolution, fine. The problems that arise is that there are 
non-Christians who shouldn't have to be exposed to Creationism but because 
this is your religion clearly your side is the right side. It is an 
intractable position which is why arguments like this happen. I am not so 
much trying to change your religious views as I am pointing out that my 
views are going to be different from many others.

The other issue here is that electing to withdraw your children from 
learning about evolution sets a dangerous precedent. If you shield your 
children from challenges to the doctrines of your religion, are you really 
doing your children or your faith any real service? From a legislative 
side, it creates a situation in which one can cite a religious view and 
essentially demand an exemption. The government lacks the efficiency to 
deal with everyday stuff, so I really don't want to see that go down the 
rabbit hole. But in the immediate consequence, you are not teaching your 
kids to defend their faith but rather to dig in their heels and essentially 
ignore any argument, regardless of its validity. If this happens enough, 
you get a sect of Christians that have a rather weird understanding of the 
sciences and problems meeting people in the middle. Rather than demand that 
people not have to learn the theory of evolution, learn how to rectify your 
faith with the world. You will not agree with everyone, as even as I write 
this I concede I am unlikely to alter your position. But I want you to have 
to defend your position, to be able to come back with a valid point, not 
just a quote from your religious book, which is more than likely not my 
religious book. If I quoted the Norse Edda to you as justification to my 
views, you would simply dismiss it as not being your religion, so in that 
regard I hope you see the contradiction.

Would you prefer your children be exposed the the Vedic origin of life on 
earth, or the Aztec creation story? You could take the part where it says 
everything bore fruit according to its kind that God created DNA to be 
self-sustainable, that as the world changed, life would change with it. All 
evolution states is that every organism has the genetics of its 
forebearers. We can demonstrate that genes change, mutations occur. This 
simply means that everything is the cummulative mutations of its 
forebearers. That much is more or less indisputable.

I don't think you understand the concept of evolution. Let me put it in a 
simple way so you are not confused. This is natural selection: A mosquito 
population is introduced to a virus that kills most of the population. The 
survivors  are naturally immune because they express traits that help them 
survive. They reproduce and become the majority of the population because 
most of them now express that trait. Keep in mind this is a trait they all 
carry but now all express. It's not a unique mutation, therefore these 
mosquitos will never become dragon flies or beetles. For that to occur, the 
theory of evolution relies on random mutations to create new genetic 
material, which to this day there is NO EVIDENCE OF. Natural selection IS 
NOT EVOLUTION. The galapagos finches interbreed and are the same species. 
None of you have explained anything. All you do is say, "Its a prime 
example of evolution" or "it's the basis of evolution" without 
understanding what you are talking about. You are just repeating what you 
were told in middle school.

Your molescules in motion universe still has a huge gaping sink hole that

profanity, and unwarranted teasing. You could knowingly be wrong (and you 
are) but as long as you receive cheers from all your likeminded pals, 
you’re content with it. I’ll respond to your reply nevertheless.

You say right and wrong is in one’s DNA. REALLY!!! (I shouldn’t be 
surprised at this but I’m thinking many atheist believe this ridiculous 
idea) I’m guessing you’re equating right and wrong behavior with 
instinctive behavior that you find in the animal world, like eating your 
young, mother animal fighting to the death to save her young, and all the 
other animal behaviors that animals do which is very predictable 
respectively within each group. Humans are not animals (atheists like to 
believe they are, so they can excuse the despicable behaviors humans 
commit), humans have minds, they can reason, think lofty thoughts, think 
logically, dream, have aspirations, etc. Humans choose whether to do good 
or to sin. Human mothers can choose to save their children (or not) even if 
the governing power over them orders them to have them killed (like Moses’ 
mother) in contrast female hamsters for example will instinctly eat many of 
their young to (some theorize) increase the chance of survival of those 
remaining (was it a moral dilemma for the hamster mother?). Whereas animals 
who do will always fight to the death to protect their young, human mothers 
can give birth and choose to discard their children in the trashcan of a 
public rest room (or not). And let’s just suppose you are right, it’s in 
our DNA, can anyone be held accountable for anything they do? You couldn’t 
fault a person for slaughtering a crowd of people any more than having a 
f***k’ed up penis from birth.

You also believe the government decides right from wrong? So Nazi Germany 
was “right” in committing genocide to further the Arian “race” and if the 
government makes into law forcing everyone to be baptize in the name of the 
Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, it’d be right and you’d comply? Homosexuality 
was outlawed in many countries in the not so long ago past so it was right 
then? (for the record homosexuality is a sin, salvation must be willingly 
received)

Bottom line, morality would be meaningless if all you had to work with was 
molecules and motion. There be no obligatory authority; things just happen 
and one’s “opinion” would not be able less wrong than another’s, might 
would make right. In the same vein, how do you explain logic in a universe 
where all you have is molecules in motion? Think it through logically 
please and see what ridiculous conclusions you arrive at.

Moving on to your criticism of God’s Word, it’s plainly obvious to any 
Biblical minded Christian that you know very little to nothing about the 
Bible and like to do what every opponent likes to do and take verses and 
passages out of context. Let’s get the whole Hell/condemnation piece out of 
the way first. The Gospel is the good news it’s called that because its 
message is the only way to salvation. In contrast, the bad news is, 
everyone is guilty before a Holy God and rightly deserving of Hell and 
heading there after this life. But if you believe in Jesus as Lord and 
Savior, your sins are forgiven and Christ’s righteousness is imputed to you 
so that in the presence of the Almighty Father, you’re as one who has never 
sinned. Therefore If a Christian sins he doesn’t go to Hell, he’s already 
justified. If someone who claims to be a Christian who habitually sins and 
has the mind of an unbeliever (God knows the heart, man can tell by the 
“fruit” produced), then he or she has never been saved. There are many 
warnings in God’s Word to His own to judge themselves lest they find 
themselves to have never been saved. I could not call you or Hitler a 
Christian any more than you can call me an atheist (..you shall know them 
by their fruit). Matthew 7:21-23 “Not everyone who says to me, ‘Lord, 
Lord,’ will enter the kingdom of heaven… And then will I declare to them, 
‘I never knew you; depart from me, you workers of lawlessness.’

Your attempts at trying to shock me with verses such as lusting at a woman 
in your heart is equivalent to adultery is right and true and Jesus was 
correcting people’s misconceptions of sin. He pointed out that sin was 
never merely the outward actions but lies in the heart. Sin has always been 
a heart issue, so you could hate your brother without a cause in your heart 
and that would be equivalent to murder. That is why Jesus was crucified and 
died but raised from the dead the third day. His resurrection is evidence 
that His sacrifice was sufficient to forgive the sins of all who would 
believe in Him therefore saving them from Hell and giving them new lives to 
live for God.

On the mangled penis, woman teachers, and the “so much more” subject, I 
want to write this first. Why should it surprise Christians or matter to 
Christians that you disagree with God’s judiciary standard that He imposed 
on the nation of Israel? Why should it surprise Christians or matter to 
Christians that you disagree with God’s moral law as revealed in His Word? 
You speak as if there’s this universal law or standard that you and I and 
everyone else has and therefore can judge the Christian God. I’ll point out 
again that your view of the universe (molecules in motion) cannot produce 
obligatory authority or a universal transcendent standard of moral 
behavior. Killing a bus load of children is not morally wrong in a universe 
comprised only of molecules in motion. Since the Christian worldview can 
produce a universal standard (and everything else necessary for our 
existence), the transcendent God with whom we have to give an account (and 
He alone is not subject to what He imposes on His creation) can do whatever 
He deems necessary and good. Logically He alone can define good and evil, 
right from wrong, etc.

For Deut. 23:1-8 (which includes deliberate disfiguring of the penis) these 
verses are for the preserving of the purity and honour of the families of 
Israel, by excluding such as would be a disgrace to them. What form this 
took is such that even Ruth (from Book of Ruth) a Moabite (v.3) became a 
convert and entered into the genealogy of the incarnate Son of God. God’s 
mercy and grace always triumphs.

For 1 Tim. 2:11-14 (women should not have authority over the man) the 
“useless women” part is not in the Bible so is that you expressing your 
opinion? You took these verses out of context as usual. Cleary it’s 
speaking about church government. And no, it wouldn’t be silly for an

unbeliever (Acts 16). God made the man the authority figure not only in the

responsible for its success or failure, because even though it was Eve who 
was deceived by the serpent, Adam forever shouldered the blame.

Sexual immorality is a serious sin deserving of death (that’s the justice 
that is rightly deserved but God is forgiving and gracious if one repents 
and believes in Christ), which includes adultery, prostitution, whoredom, 
sex with animals, same sex intercourse, etc. God wants to preserve purity 
and confine sex to one man and one woman in the marriage relationship.

On the subject of incest charged against God, you’re an atheist, a 
materialist, you’re an animal, a damn dirty ape, should incest matter,

appear simultaneously on the scene throughout the earth and immediately

(Leviticus 18:6->, 20:11->). Here, you not only failed to understand the

So in conclusion we’re learned that Biaggio wasted a lot typing on the

comments.text:
Let's get down to the 'facts' of creationism sure. the universe is 6,000 
years old? Well how come we can see galaxies over a couple million light 
years away? Why can we date fossils back further than this? Why can we 
count more rings on some trees than this? Why when we drill holes into the 
polar icecaps we can count layers that are representing seasons going back 
millions of years. Hell even the recorded history of china and Egypt go 
back over 6,000 years ago? 

In the late 19th century Astronomer Edwin Hubble looks to the stars through 
his telescope and notices the stars are moving apart and he couldn't figure 
out why. They debated the topic for years and at one of these debates Fred 
Hoyle remarked 'it was like there was a big bang' because of the expansion. 
They went out and listened and there was this hiss sound everywhere they 
pointed, astronomers running the numbers and doing maths predicted that in 
the cosmos left over would be this echo of energy left over from the Big 
Bang that would be detectable and they dedicated it they built the cosmic 
observatory of background emissions and it matched the astronomers 
predictions exactly, you have to respect that and even if you don't accept 
that the Big Bang is a fact you have to accept that it is a very likely 
theory (much more so than creationism anyway).

The Big Bang theory is based on facts you can observe for yourself not a 
book that could of been wrote by any pipe smoker on his day off. I still 
respect creationists but if you wanna believe in an origin with talking 
snakes over one with evidence then I've no respect for your mind at all.

your statement about theists. Putting it bluntly, they have the right to be 
irrational morons. This is not to say that it is without consequence. Most 
of the younger folks are realizing the significance of education, and are 
focused on practicing pragmatism instead of outdated ideologies that 
contradict fact. Going back to what Neil has stated, “Religion is an ever 
shrinking sphere of scientific ignorance”. People in this country, per the 
1st Amendment, have the right to be uneducated idiots. The sociological 
consequence, from what I can see, is the younger generation questioning and 
naturally rebeling against antiquated ideologues. This will make way for 
the next progressive steps and usher in new fresh ideas and new 
discoveries. I know it’s an optimistic view, but the trends seem to be 
swinging in this direction.

comments.author: buttface112211

comments.text:
+Foreordained 777
"the lack of a case for evolution is clear from the fact that no one has 
ever seen it happen."

This is simply because you've redefined evolution to be an impossibility, 
mainly because you've inserted undefined terms like "kinds".

Evolution is still occurring. How old are you, and how long would it take a 
single gene, or a collection of genes, to spread throughout an entire 
population of organisms. Lets use lions as an example. A lioness reaches 
sexual maturity at the age of four, and the gestation period is about 3.5 
to 4 months. How long would it take a single gene to spread throughout the 
population?

And, there are observed instances of organisms adapting to new environments 
especially in instances where humans have transplanted organisms to 
unfamiliar environments.

http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/04/080421-lizard-evolution.html
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nylon-eating_bacteria
http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evolibrary/news/060901_mussels
http://www.livescience.com/18276-lizards-show-evolution.html
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Underground_mosquito

"and there should be many "transitional" forms that we could observe."

We must define our terms. Is it fair to say a transitional form is a 
population of organisms, extant or extinct, that represents an intermediate 
state between two population of organisms that share apparent inherited 
traits?

"What we see instead, of course, is an array of distinct "kinds" of plants 
and animals with many varieties within each kind, but with very clear and 
-- apparently -- unbridgeable gaps between the kinds. That is, for example, 
there are many varieties of dogs and many varieties of cats, but no "dats" 
or "cogs." Such variation is often called microevolution"

Can you define macroevolution?

"and these minor horizontal (or downward) changes"

"Horizontal" is definitionally opposed to "downward".

"Evolutionary geneticists have often experimented on fruit flies and other 
rapidly reproducing species to induce mutational changes hoping they would 
lead to new and better species,"

These experiments have not been conducted by just geneticists. The goal of 
these experiments were also not to produce a "new and better species". What 
is a "better species"? This terminology makes no sense. Additionally, the 
goal of these experiments were never to explicitly produce "new and better 
species", it was to explore the development of reproductive isolation.

"but these have all failed to accomplish their goal. No truly new species 
has ever been produced, let alone a new "basic kind.""

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speciation
http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/faq-speciation.html
http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/speciation.html

"A current leading evolutionist, Jeffrey Schwartz, professor of 
anthropology at the University of Pittsburgh, has recently acknowledged 
that...."

He's a "current leading evolutionist"? How exactly does one get this title, 
and why does he deserve it? Who's decided that he's a "current leading 
evolution"? I'll tell you what this looks like to me; it looks like in a 
desperate effort to quote mine you attached this label to Prof. Schwartz or 
simply pasted the title from some creationist website that you pulled the 
quote from. Find me a larger excerpt that puts this quote in context, and 
I'll accept that he's not being misrepresented in any way.

Even if this mid-sentence quote does present the same notion in a larger 
context, so what? This man can't be wrong? I already linked multiple 
sources that document multiple observed instances of multiple types of 
speciation, both artificial and natural.

"The scientific method traditionally has required experimental observation 
and replication."

I've already provided sources that fulfill both of these criterion.

"The fact that macroevolution (as distinct from microevolution) has never 
been observed would seem to exclude it from the domain of true science."

Define macroevolution.

And, as I continue to search your quotes verbatim, I realize you've simply 
plagiarized an entire webpage (
http://www.icr.org/home/resources/resources_tracts_scientificcaseagainstevolution/) 
and presented it as your own. This only makes me think my efforts were 
probably a waste of time because, if you respond at all, it will simply be 
with more plagiarized creationist articles.
comments.author: buttface112211

comments.text:
+TheLegendOfRandy First of all, the lack of a case for evolution is clear 
from the fact that no one has ever seen it happen. If it were a real 
process, evolution should still be occurring, and there should be many 
"transitional" forms that we could observe. What we see instead, of course, 
is an array of distinct "kinds" of plants and animals with many varieties 
within each kind, but with very clear and -- apparently -- unbridgeable 
gaps between the kinds. That is, for example, there are many varieties of 
dogs and many varieties of cats, but no "dats" or "cogs." Such variation is 
often called microevolution, and these minor horizontal (or downward) 
changes occur fairly often, but such changes are not true "vertical" 
evolution.
Evolutionary geneticists have often experimented on fruit flies and other 
rapidly reproducing species to induce mutational changes hoping they would 
lead to new and better species, but these have all failed to accomplish 
their goal. No truly new species has ever been produced, let alone a new 
"basic kind."
A current leading evolutionist, Jeffrey Schwartz, professor of anthropology 
at the University of Pittsburgh, has recently acknowledged that:
. . . it was and still is the case that, with the exception of Dobzhansky's 
claim about a new species of fruit fly, the formation of a new species, by 
any mechanism, has never been observed.
The scientific method traditionally has required experimental observation 
and replication. The fact that macroevolution (as distinct from 
microevolution) has never been observed would seem to exclude it from the 
domain of true science. Even Ernst Mayr, the dean of living evolutionists, 
longtime professor of biology at Harvard, who has alleged that evolution is 
a "simple fact," nevertheless agrees that it is an "historical science" for 
which "laws and experiments are inappropriate techniques by which to 
explain it. One can never actually see evolution in action.

comments.text:
+megadeth22885 Climategate has been debunked a long time ago:

http://www.skepticalscience.com/Climategate-CRU-emails-hacked.htm

http://grist.org/climate-skeptics/2011-02-28-what-we-have-and-havent-learned-from-climategate/

I'm not 100% sure of global warming being strictly man-made myself, but 
your whole argumentation is very flawed so far.

You advocate skepticism, which is a very good position, yet you blindly 
give into such hoax as climategate without even checking falsifying sources 
(if you had, you'd have realized how that particular proof is shaky), 
which, coming from a scientist, is a very odd behaviour.

Another one is dismissing the Carboniferous extinction as "just a theory, 
and a rather small and unpopular one at that", which makes me wonder 
whether you know what a scientific theory is (hint: it's not a hypothesis 
and even less an educated guess), which in turn cast a serious doubt on 
your claim to be a scientist.

Besides, the Carboniferous extinction isn't small and unpopular. It's an 
accepted scientific theory accounting for the extinction of giant 
invertebrates and many, many plant species, among other things. It's just 
not as famous among the general public as the K-T or the Permian ones, 
because not as spectacular. Which you would know if you had done basic 
research on the topic (no need to be a paleontologist here). And yes, CO2 
was the main cause.

For the record, I haven't seen the Cosmos episode where it's mentioned yet. 
Not in the US either. I also agree that TV documentaries should be more 
cautious and strict, because the general public tend to believe them at 
face value (I'd have examples of bad science in documentaries, but that 
would be a huge digression).

I wouldn't normally give a damn about your credentials since I don't 
believe only scientists should be allowed to discuss science, but it's 
something you repeatedly use to position yourself above the "non-scientist 
plebe":

>> "of course you believe that, because you arent a real scientist "

>> "they are like an illiterate person being read a book by someone else 
and then trusting that individual is reading exactly what is on the pages 
and not making something up "

Which is why I repeatedly asked you what is your brand of science. In other 
words, what makes you more qualified than Laurenz or anyone else on the 
topic of climate change that we should take your evidence any more 
seriously than theirs, since qualification seems so important to you?
comments.author: Virginia I

+megadeth22885
Now, because you are emphasising the small amount of carbon dioxide and 
it's small effect on the climate change:
I've found this (Source: 
reportingclimatescience[dot]com/news-stories/article/carbon-dioxide-prevents-earth-from-becoming-an-ice-world.html) 
(link is too big to provide, I will do so later):
"Within 50 years the global average temperature would plunge by 35C to -21C 
without the thermostatic warming provided by atmospheric carbon dioxide. 
Despite the fact that water vapour and clouds account for around three 
quarters of the Earth's greenhouse effect, it is carbon dioxide that is the 
single most important climate-relevant greenhouse gas in the Earth's 
atmosphere, according to the paper."
So, the overall rise of temperature caused just by carbon dioxide is 35°C.
Now, according to another source 
(www[dot]geocraft[dot]com/WVFossils/greenhouse_data.html), the total 
concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere is about 370 000 ppb (quite an 
outdated number because if I recall correctly, we have already gotten to 
400 000 ppb), while the manmade co2 of that is about 12 000 -> about 3 %
As 3% of 35°C is about 1°C, we have now estimated that human made CO2 
contributes about 1°C. (which is about what I heard and it is quite a lot 
if you ask me)

Now, of course in this calculations there are probably some numbers that 
are inaccurate and maybe I have done a mistake (tell me if you find one). 
All I am trying to tell you is: I do not "believe a television show over 
common sense and facts" as you stated.

comments.text:
+megadeth22885 Actually, I have never seen 'Cosmos' so far. Why? Because I 
am not living in the United States and I am generally refusing Television. 
But does it really matter whether I have watched it or not? I did not 
answer you to "defend" Cosmos, maybe all your accusations are actually 
justified, I don't know (as I have said, I did not watch it).

However, I commented here to tell you this:
If the majority of climate scientists (actual scientists, not people like 
me as you have pointed out correctly) believe with an astounding majority 
in climate change we should trust them this time and do something about it.

Imagine a similar case:
A meteor is falling towards earth and the scientists say that the 
probability of it hitting the earth is, let's say 80%. Also they say the 
nearer the meteor is coming, the more accurately can they say whether it 
will hit. Now, the problem is, once the accuracy hit's, lets say 95%, we 
are too late to send Bruce Willis (little joke) to save us and the meteor 
will hit earth. Now, we can deal something with the meteor right now, to 
save the earth completely. Of course, this saving action costs a lot of 
money. Do you think we should discuss about saving the planet from the 
meteor until it is too late but we know 100% for sure that it is hitting 
us? Of course not, we need to deal with it right now, even if there is the 
small percentage that the meteor is not hitting us in the first place.

It is the same with climate change: We should do something about that right 
now before it is too late. Maybe we get lucky and there was no climate 
change in the first place. But the probability is so high that I (and I am 
certain there are a lot of very smart guys who agree with me) think it is 
not to be risked. Even if it means that we have to sacrifice some of our 
wealth for it.
Again, I agree with you being skeptical about climate change. So am I, 
however: Know your place! Let 97% of climate scientists do their job 
because, after all, why do we have them to warn us about things like that 
if we don't listen to them when they have something to say?
comments.author: Laurenz Baumhoer

comments.text:
+megadeth22885 
Nice fallacy ("either you're with me or against me" Seriously?)

Do you think I waited to watch this show to "believe" in climate change? I 
can *experience* climate change. I don't need to be told, I live it.

Climate change is a fact. It's also nothing exceptional. It's happened many 
times before, and on some occasions, did cause mass extinctions.

What remains to be proven beyond the shadow of a doubt are the exact causes 
and whether or not human's influence is significant enough to turn a mild 
warming into an actual feedback loop hazard. 97% of scientists belonging in 
relevant branches think so, so maybe... yes?

Meanwhile, reducing CO2 emission by trying to find alternate energy sources 
can't hurt (except if you're in the oil/coal business, that is).

If twenty MDs, including generalists, gastroenterologists and hepatologists 
tell you you're on the brink of liver failure, as evidenced by bloodwork, 
imagery, and that nice yellow tinge in your eyes, would you continue to 
deny it because you don't want to stop drinking alcohol, or would you stop 
drinking, find another way to have fun, and start treatment, just in case?

And you didn't answer my question. Which branch of science do you hail from?

comments.text:
If stating the obvious (i.e. this is the translation of a translation of 
the quote of a quote; so stick to the original) is getting all high and 
mighty, then so be it. Nice personal attack, btw. Not your first, and not 
your last.

*Ekplirono is Modern Greek*, sir scholar. The Ancient Greek word used in 
Matthew is πληρῶσαι (plerosai). It means fulfill alright, but do you 
actually use a Modern Greek dictionary for your Bible studies? What did 
they teach you at seminary? (Am I getting high and mighty, here, by 
pointing that enormous blunder? Seriously, it's like me getting my physics 
from Aristotle)

*On the cross he said "It is finnished"*

First, I usually don't fret over spelling, but it's "finished". Written 
like that, It looks as though he meant "turned into something coming from 
Finland", and it's really distracting.

Second, you do realize that this interpretation of "finished" is one among 
many possibilities. Personally, I'd say that means that the whole ordeal is 
done and his mission complete -- which, btw, isn't quite accurate, since he 
still have to resurrect at this point to actually establish the "new 
religion". Without resurrection, no christianity.

I know that you don't consider my interpretation as worthwhile, since I'm a 
lowly atheist raised catholic who knows nothing, and you hold the Truth, 
but it's still a valid one.

Regardless, that doesn't take into account "until Heaven and Earth has 
passed away" in Mat. 5:18.

I'm looking at biblehub right now, with commentaries from half a dozen 
theologians, and the general consensus isn't that it means "when it's 
accomplished" (which according to you happened on Good Friday):

*but He says: **onwards to the destruction of the world the law will not 
lose its validity in the slightest point**, by which popular expression 
(Luke **16:17**; Job **14:12**) the duration of the law after the final 
catastrophe of the world is neither taught nor excluded. That the law, 
however, fulfilled as to its ideal nature, will endure in the new world, is 
clear from 1 Corinthians 13:3 (ἀγάπη); 1 Peter **1:25**; 2 Peter 3:3 
(δικαιοσύνη).*
[Meyer's NT Exegetical Commentary]

What do you make of that?
comments.author: Virginia I

comments.text:
+Virginia_I You should really try to improve your self esteem. I attended 
Bible College and Seminary and I have a greek text beside me so don't get 
all high and mighty with me.. Ekplirono (greek word in english) translates 
to fill or complete as in fulfill your duties. In Matthew 5:17 ff Jesus 
signifies that he came not to tear up or destroy the OT law, scripture was 
inspired but it also pointed to his coming and accomplishing his mission. 
He completed the OT law with regard to ceremonial law, sacrificial law, etc 
because he kept them all and thus could become the perfect sacrifice, the 
final sacrifice. On the cross he said "It is finnished". Why is this 
significant? In matthew 5:18 Jesus says the law remains until "all is 
accomplished" guess what, he accomplished what the law prepared for him to 
accomplish. In the immediate context how does he describe the law. Five 
times he says "you have heard that it was said" and then follows with"but I 
say to you". Thereby demonstrating that his law takes the place of moses 
law. And it isn't in terms of continuing all the OT laws but his new 
covenant laws. During the last supper he gave the disciples the cup which 
represented his blood and called it the NEW COVENANT not the continuation 
of the Old.

The book of Matthew was written to prove from the Jewish Scriptures that 
Jesus fulfilled the requirements of messiahship. Matthew often said Jesus 
acted "to fulfill" what was said through one prophet or another (Matthew 
1:22; 2:5, 15, 17, 23; 4:14; 8:17, etc.). One can read through the book of 
Matthew and note all the times that a reference is made to the Old 
Testament as being fulfilled in Jesus. It is surprising, indeed.
Jesus said in Matthew 3:15 that "all righteousness" should be fulfilled in 
his actions. Luke 24:25-27, 44-45 and John 5:39-47 are also instructive on 
this point. These verses show that Jesus was interested in showing how the 
Hebrew Scriptures had himself as their object. He was the Messiah of whom 
all the Jewish holy writings had spoken of.
The Tyndale New Testament Commentary on Matthew offers another view of 
"fulfill." It emphasizes that Jesus was bringing the meaning of the 
Scriptures to their intended completion. It says: "Jesus is bringing that 
to which the Old Testament looked forward; his teaching will transcend the 
Old Testament revelation, but, far from abolishing it, is himself its 
intended culmination" (page 114).

+tokingcircle "A theory cannot be proven right; it can only be proven wrong 
with evidence and data." Truth, but The Law of gravity is not considered a 
theory, I think the fact that the whole universe is held together by the 
force of gravity, let alone us on this earth, is more than enough evidence 
to make it a fact. Hence the Term "Law of Gravity". Evolution, while still 
a valid option, has no other ground to hold it than the bones of things 
that MIGHT be related to us, but we can't be sure (to put it very simply). 
Believe me, I'd love to believe in evolution myself, but the evidence is 
not solid, and backed by only theories, thoughts, wonders. And don't get me 
wrong, I couldn't physically prove that there is a God to anyone. Just not 
going to happen like that. But, it makes more Mathematical sense for there 
to be some sort (god or otherwise) thing to have crafted all that we know 
about space and time. The universe is like a giant clock, or a well knitted 
cloth. Both don't just happen to fall in place by chance. Both have had to 
have a begining by something. Much like the big bang, something caused it, 
and something behind the something caused that, and we don;t know what it 
was, yet.

comments.text:
A theory can be comprised of laws such as the laws of gravity. But as a 
whole it is newtonian theory of gravity. A theory cannot be proven right; 
it can only be proven wrong with evidence and data.  As long as the theory 
of evolution isn't proven wrong, it stays valid.  But the theory itself can 
be altered if new evidences arise and scientific community is ok with it 
just as the theory of gravity by newton was taken a step beyond by einstein 
with is theory of relativity but it itself is incomplete and we are waiting 
for someone or a group of scientists to come and take it one step beyond. 
 Also for the missing link, we have evidence by fossil records that shows 
the gradual change of our ancestors starting from the division from 
chimps/bonobos which occurred about 5 million years ago. We haven't found 
the "missing link" which just means our closest extinct relative before the 
emergence of home sapiens but that doesn't mean that all the other 
evidences are not valid.  What is astonishing is that when a 
fundamentalist/creationist tries to prove evolution wrong they say we are 
not from monkeys/ chimpanzees; of course we are not, we have a common 
ancestor with chimps and monkeys which happened to be alive about 60 
million years ago.  But they don't grasp the fact that earth is 4 billion 
years old; to them, it is about 10000 years old but the sad thing is, we 
have found the traces of civilizations dating back about 12000 years. And i 
am ok with one being religious; we live in a country that promotes freedom 
of religion but when it hinders the progression of science, imagination and 
dream, that's when I get pissed off. Because at some point one must come to 
the conclusion that a holy book was written before the knowledge of science 
and we have the ability to answer questions that baffled people before 
science with science and that empowers us.  We also have the ability to ask 
questions that lead us to a better understanding of the universe.

comments.text:
+prosperomage
Just a nitpick:

To be fair, the flood isn't a myth per se. I suppose (this is a widely held 
speculation as far as I know) what the myth of the flood is referencing is 
the flooding of the area that today is the Black Sea, when after the last 
Ice Age the sea level rose to the point where the waters of the 
Mediterranean Sea began forming and spilling out over the Bosporus strait 
and within a really short period of time (by geological terms) created the 
Black Sea. Until then, all that existed there was a large freshwater lake 
with a significantly (significantly enough) lower sea level than the 
Mediterranean, so it was flooded and raised to the ocean's level.

Obviously that's a big chunk of land we're talking about here, and this 
would have forced everyone living there to get moving and find a new place 
to live VERY QUICKLY, and I guess not a large percentage of the population 
there made it out alive and well. Hence "flood" and " 'biblical' 
catastrophe". It happened many thousand years ago, but tales of this might 
have been handed down all the way to the Hebrews.
comments.author: Abaddon133

No , Moses didn't write the Torah nor any other part of the Tanakh (old 
testament). The Torah was written over several hundred years by various 
authors.

synoptic Gospels - first, Jesus had no disciples named Mark or Luke. 
Secondly, the NT was written in "koine" Greek - Jesus' 12 followers spoke 
Aramaic and certainly weren't educated men who would have known Greek. The 
Gospels were written by Greek Christians decades after the alleged events 
occured. We see this clearly because their understanding of Judaism was 
limited - no Jew thought the moshiach (messiah) was divine. The messiah is 
just a political/religious leader who would arise to save Israel in a time 
of troubles.  Also, the imagery of the "lamb of god" is incorrect - lamb is 
served at Passover and does NOT have anything to do with sacrifice for sin. 
 The sin sacrifice was made by the high priest on Yom Kippur and the 
sacrifice was a bull, not a lamb. Greek Christians, not knowing this, 
mistakenly thought Jesus' death around the time of Passover had some 
sacrificial symbolism.  But they were mistaken.

comments.text:
+Michael Yang First of all, I consider myself a pantheist, not an atheist. 
Some people, like Richard Dawkins argue they are the same thing, but IMHO 
they are different in some core philosophical values.

To answer your question, I think fields, particles, and waves are all there 
is to it (so no supernatural powers). However, they are much more than you 
think. For example, we recently found out that consciousness is linked to 
microtubules in our brain which are in quantum superposition meaning they 
can exist in multiple positions at the same time. This can even mean your 
consciousness can escape corporal death! Also, feelings, personalities, and 
intellect are produced by extremely complicated neural patterns in our 
brain which still in large part a mystery to us. Neural cells are all 
matters and energy. Neuroscience is a science. It's not metaphysics or 
anything. 

Again, I'm a Bayesian thinker. I'm ready to be wrong. In fact, I'm excited 
to be wrong because it means a new mind blowing discovery is made.

comments.text:
+Michael Yang The reason why your responses are so painfully obnoxious, 
besides your scientific illiteracy, is your inability to carefully read and 
construe responses to your posts. I certainly did not claim that evolution 
is needed for computers. Or did I say 100% of scientists believe in 
evolution (I said "most"). Also I stated multiple times that evolution has 
nothing to do with "something from nothing." Stop bringing this to 
discussion.

Also, you said "how can anyone convince you that evolution is nonsense when 
it is and you still believe in it." I've stated multiple times that all it 
takes is a piece of evidence that is inconsistent with the theory 
(disproof) or an alternate explanation that is more probable. In fact, most 
scientifically literate people are Bayesian thinkers. We don't really 
believe anything 100%, and we are always ready to be wrong. We are never 
100% confident in anything we believe. This is why we can make discoveries 
and make adjustments to knowledge unlike religious fundamentalists who 
reference their "holy books" as infallible axioms. So before you have a 
better explanation or a disproof, please don't call this theory nonsense. 
It's the most solid theory there is right now. 

You are claiming there is no evidence for evolution because YOU are not 
seeing them disregarding observations made by scientists who actively seek 
these using better equipment and methods. Simply Google for evolutionary 
mutation examples. I find examples in bacteria such as E Coli more 
believable because of their fast reproduction cycles. It showcases the 
effect of evolution better.

Also, the reason why we can't see "apes to humans" examples is because it 
takes too long for us to see it. However if we can detect a few changes 
during a reasonable course of time, we can logically conclude that over 
many more years, these changes will accumulate and achieve a much more 
dramatic result. If you understand 1 + 1 = 2, then we don't have to explain 
why 1000 + 1000 = 2000. It's logic.

comments.text:
What happened before the big bang is a good question, but also a wrong 
question because it asssumes there was time 'before' the big bang. Since 
time began with the big bang, nothing was 'before' the big bang.

But of course you mean 'what caused the big bang'. We don't know this, but 
there are a few hypotheses. For instance M-theory and string theory. They 
assume we are a 3D world (universe) inside a more dimensional space. Lots 
of other 3D universes exist next to us in this multidimensional space. Some 
people would argue this is far fetched, but think about it: we used to 
think we lived in the only solar system in this vast space. Then we 
corrected this, and we assumed multiple solar systems exist and we believed 
we were living in the only galaxy. Then we corrected this, and now we know 
there are much more galaxies in the universe. At this point we believe 
there is only 1 universe, but why wouldnt there be many more?

M-theory suggests the big bang could have been caused by the collision of 2 
branes (2 universes), and that's where our material came from.
So you'll probably say 'but then this multidimensional space needs an 
explanation, and that explanation is god'. But this isn't true. Since time 
exists inside universes, the multidimensional space (in which our universe 
'floats') may not have a time dimension, and could therefore be 'eternal' 
(although this word loses its meaning if there is no time dimension).
So this space could have always existed, and the universes could come into 
being in this space.
That's of course a very simplistic version, if you truly want to understand 
M-theory you'll have to study physics and understand complex mathematics.

comments.text:
+Mike Chrisman So you don't *exactly* know what the Big Bang is. You have a 
good grasp of it, but some serious misconceptions too.

And please, keep in mind that what follows is not meant to belittle you 
(i.e. "Look at the stupid christian") but only to demonstrate how your 
premise "nothing became something" (which would be quite a feat) is based 
on your own misunderstanding and not the theory itself.

I also assume (and hope) that you're ready to actually read what follows 
and at least consider it, and think about it, as opposed to dismiss it with 
a bible verse or a "I know because I know". :) Whether you choose to 
believe it is up to you, I'm not trying to convert you, just to explain. 
Unfortunately, it's gonna be a long one.

SO:

First a very short version:

The whole universe used to be very hot and very dense. It's expanding and 
cooling, which allows the creation of elements, stars and planets through 
laws and forces.

Now, the very long one:

*>>  the universe was smaller than an atom at some point, <<*

The "universe" here is the whole thing. All matter and energy, but also 
forces and space-time. This last point is very important. 

"Smaller than an atom", "at some point" is a misrepresentation, and a bit 
besides the point. The first two tenets of the BBT are:

*1. The whole universe used to be almost infinitely hot* (lots of 
concentrated energy)

*2. The whole universe used to be almost infinitely dense* (lots of 
concentrated matter)

Under such extreme conditions, matter and energy don't behave like we're 
used to. Fundamental forces (gravity, electromagnetism, weak and strong 
forces) are merged. There are no molecules, no atoms, no protons, electrons 
or neutrons. On quantum level, even the basic quarks don't exist as such. 
Only a soup of matter and energy with very little structure. Time and space 
(space-time, actually, one single thing) don't exist either. It's almost 
infinitely compressed and slowed to the point of non-existence.

So you can't have "smaller than an atom" (no space => no size), or "at some 
point" (no time). The whole universe is in another state, a bit like water 
becomes solid (ice) when it's cold and gaseous (steam) when it's hot.

The best example of such a different state would be neutron stars 
(pulsars), which have been observed multiple times (so we *know* they 
exist, we've seen and analysed them, they're fact). A typical neutron star 
has a 20 km diameter (12.5 miles) and the mass of eight Suns. Due to 
density, gravity and EM are so high that the core is reduced to a "neutron 
soup" (hence the name). No elements, no atoms, no protons, no electrons, 
only neutrons. A neutron star is in another state than, say, the Sun, and 
lots of weird things happen around and within it, including to space-time.

The next step would be a black hole. Even higher density, so much so that 
light itself can't escape the gravitational pull and time slows down to a 
near full stop if you're close enough.

Take that even further, and you have what the whole universe used to be: no 
time, no space, forces merged, matter and energy so concentrated they don't 
behave like they would under our current "normal" conditions.


*>> that particle HAD TO BE SOMEWHERE, it can't be in "nothing" and just 
blow up and start expanding, and then how does that little particle turn 
into planets and the sun? hm... tell me that <<*

It's not a *particle*. Not even close. It's much more than that (see above).

*"had to be somewhere"*. Sure, but remember that "somewhere" means 
something different than "at some place" since there's no space as we 
understand it.

We don't know "where" the universe was, so I won't tell you it was like 
this and that. We're still looking into it. Taking a look at M Theory 
(Multiverses, 11 dimensions) gives a satisfying answer *to me* : the 
universe was and still is in a dimension beyond the four we know and 
perceive. But not everybody agrees on that, and while it's mathematically 
sound (or so I'm told, I don't pretend to understand math at this level), 
it hasn't been strictly observed yet.

So now that we've established what the universe was according to the BBT, 
here's the third and last tenet:

*3. The universe is expanding*

This is observed via light shifting (Doppler effect), and we also have good 
snapshots of the universe shortly after the BB (Cosmic Microwave Background 
and recently, gravitational lines forming, the latter being the closest and 
more direct proof we've ever had. Yay!).

*But no explosion here, just expansion*. Very, very fast at the beginning, 
but no detonation (meaning no detonator). The BBT doesn't state what caused 
it, why it happened (we can hypothesize, though) and even when (we have a 
pretty good idea, but it's not part of the BBT).

*>>and then how does that little particle turn into planets and the sun?<<*

Wow. I'm gonna try to summarize as much as possible, but it's a hard one to 
explain in a post, considering I don't know what your knowledge of physics 
(general and quantic) and cosmology is. So let's try to densify information.

Keep in mind: *this is not a little particle. This is the whole universe. 
All matter, all energy, all space-time, all forces*.

Once the universe starts expanding, a lot of things happen. First, it 
changes state (we call those states "Epoch"). Time-space happens and laws 
are established (google String Theory for a nice and quite poetic possible 
explanation of how this laws are established), forces separate, starting 
with gravity and each with their own respective "strength". In our 
universe, for instance, gravity is very weak compared to electro-magnetism.

The universe starts to cool (energy isn't as concentrated) but it's still 
very hot and dense, and matter and energy all interact very quickly via 
collisions and others things happening at quantum level. They start 
organizing. First into photons, quarks (up and down, mainly), and other 
quantic thingies, then subatomic particles (neutrons, protons and 
electrons), then the first atom: Hydrogen. From there, Helium (very stable) 
and other more fragile or unstable elements such as Deuterium or Lithium, 
but in small quantity, because they're unstable or fragile. All this takes 
very little time (less than twenty minutes). Past this time, the universe 
has reached a new state where it isn't dense and hot enough anymore for 
this reactions / interactions to happen. 

Doesn't matter, though, the basic bricks are now here, and forces too to 
bind them all and turn them into many different things. Gravity will cause 
accretion, which is the way things tend to stick together to form bigger 
things with larger mass. With time, accretion creates bodies massive enough 
- with enough core pressure - that the first thermonuclear reaction can 
occur: fusion (atoms are pressed together so hard they merge and form a 
new, heavier element). This produces energy and light, and many other 
things. But more importantly, the first stars are born.

Stars are elements factories, mainly via thermonuclear fusion. Depending on 
their mass, they can produce new elements by fusing Hydrogen atoms together 
into Helium then on to heavier elements by combination, the limit being 
determined by the mass of the star. Our Sun produces Helium, Oxygen, 
Carbon, Nitrogen and other light elements, up to (iirc) Silicon. It isn't 
massive enough to go further than that (not enough core pressure).

A very massive star can fuse up to Iron, but at the very moment it does so, 
its "equilibrium" is broken, and it collapses and turns into a supernova. 
Heavier elements are created in the blast and ejected into space along with 
the rest for other bodies to catch or be formed from via gravity. What 
happens to the star afterwards is again depending on its mass. It can 
become a white dwarf, a neutron star or, for the more massive ones, a black 
hole.

(Elements are also created in star flares and in a completely different 
process called "radioactive decay", but that's another story).

So now, we know how stars and elements come into existence (and out of it 
via transformation). Onto the Solar System.

The Sun was born via accretion, like many other stars, of a thing called an 
accretion disk, which is made of elements bound together by gravity. Once 
it was born, there was still a lot of material left. 

Accretion went on, and over time, bodies started to coalesce here and there 
with the heavier elements staying close to the Sun and creating the 
telluric (rocky) planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars, and the lighter 
creating the outer gaseous giant planets, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and 
Neptune. Satellites were created the same way, being "caught" on the fly by 
their mother planet, with the notable exception of the Moon. There also was 
many more bodies to start with, ranging from asteroids to mars-sized 
planets but many disappeared through collision and/or absorption.

So here you are: from a very, very hot and dense universe containing 
everything it's made of, then expansion, you've got elements, then stars, 
then planets.

If you've read that far: first congrats for your patience, that was a long 
one. Second, what do you think of it now?

comments.text:
+GamerSketched
Either we evolved or we didn't. Either a god exists or it doesn't. Either 
2+2=4 or it doesn't. These are not subjective opinions like one's favorite 
color...they are attempted evaluations of an objective reality which are 
either correct or incorrect. The job of science (and the one thing it does 
better than ANY other system in human history) is to reliably determine 
what is correct about reality and what is not. There are objective facts 
about reality which can be discovered and when they are discovered within a 
reasonable degree of certainty, denying them is not only irrational but 
potentially harmful. Agreeing to disagree on such issues gets us 
nowhere...either as individuals or as a species. Its simply a way to 
preserve desired beliefs even in the face of contradictory evidence 
(faith). Do you not think we should all endeavor to reliably determine what 
is fact and what is fantasy?

My idea of intrinsic value is a subjective one where one's way of life 
matches their principles.  Let me put it like this. I believe people are 
born with free-will.  We have the choice to be good, loving people, or not 
(lets forget about upbringing, environment).  When I look at the 
reward/punishment system and people who operate on this system, I think 
free will is somewhat taken away from the individual. Kind of a "don't ask, 
don't question, just listen" attitude a parent would say to a child.

I do think my original comment is rather rash now that I read it.  The 
dynamics I am attacking about religion are easily seen in a academic and 
other institutions as well. Having said that I do believe mechanisms of 
reward and punishment can be a good starting tool but it will inhibit

Universities devide humanity into faculty members and those who are not.

Christianities idea of sin, as far as I ever encountered it, devides

Of course Christianity contains in all its pratices ideas of moral 
judgement. Societies were Christinanity is widespread have often developed

And I don't see how this arises by conscious manipulation by someone or in

searched for them or actively spread them for this purpose.

Morality and values have quite a lot to do with our self-respect and 
respect for others. You can show that in various experiments very 
consistently. Morality and values also have a lot to do with opportunism, 
instinctive selfishness and circumstances. The latter evenmoreso as people 
age. Young children, for example, are less discerning in who deserves help 
then older children and adults are. If there is a relation to age, I'd say 
it's a negative one at best.

I am not sure if I understand your concept of intrinsic value. To attribute 
intrinsic value to something is a subjective process. A child might value 
clrearing his room because it is rewarded with ice cream. Ice cream has 
intrinsic value to the child because it is tasty. You might say, to an 
adult a tidy room has intrinsic values, but that does not seem right. It 
has value for working more effective or somehting, which is valuable 
because it allows for earning money which allows for more ice cream which 
is still the thing with intrinsic value.
It is hard for me to think of an example where this really changes and even 
if we allow for that adults intrinsicly values some things they only valued 
for reward as children, that does not change the fact that they simply 
value some things over others, their priorities just changed as adults.
That is often related to adolescence, but in good ways as well as in bad 
ways. We don't magically start to want morally good things (we had to be 
tricked into wanting earlier) when we become adults. Just consider the 
idiotic immature things adults do for sex or money.

comments.text:

 You lament childishness but characterize religion (which has no general

I did affirm that classical conditioning was a popular upbringing style,

point was that: Learning that way has nothing to do with being a child, you 
learn that way as a child as well as adult, but both learn by many

"Why should scientists just be believed without questioning? "

THEY'RE NOT! There are absolutely NO scientific theories that are simply

to offer, that's fine. But remember that EVERYONE can verify the findings 
of the scientific community, and scientific theories ARE verified by 
others. Every single day, by thousands of people. EVERY SINGLE experiment 
that has occurred in the history of human civilization can be repeated by, 
not only other scientists, but by YOU to verify the truth of the claims. 
That reason alone is why I believe in scientific theories. I don't simply 
accept them without question. I KNOW that I can check the facts to make 
sure they're true. Science is the study of the universe and the universe 
does not stop you from studying it. The universe cannot be patented, 
protected, hidden, or become classified. So no, don't accept the Big Bang 
Theory without question. Accept it, because it has been verified and back 
up time and time again. If that isn't enough, then verify it for yourself. 
Lucky for human civilization that not only do scientists document the 
theories, they also document the methods by which they are tested. So test

application. Verifiable reliability of tests and practical application are 
two things that religion and faith are sorely lacking.

comments.text:
Lets attempt to clear something up.
The word faith has been hijacked by religion to mean belief in god. It has 
multiple meanings, while it does indeed hold the religious meaning, it also 
means confidence and trust.

faith
fāTH/Submit
noun
noun: faith
1.
complete trust or confidence in someone or something.
"this restores one's faith in politicians"
synonyms: trust, belief, confidence, conviction; More
antonyms: mistrust
2.
strong belief in God or in the doctrines of a religion, based on spiritual 
apprehension rather than proof.
synonyms: religion, church, sect, denomination, (religious) persuasion, 
(religious) belief, ideology, creed, teaching, doctrine More
a system of religious belief.
plural noun: faiths
"the Christian faith"
a strongly held belief or theory.
"the faith that life will expand until it fills the universe"
Origin

Middle English: from Old French feid, from Latin fides .

Atheism has an abundance of the former directed at science and personal 
capability while religion holds the latter meaning.
So yes, an Atheist has faith in whatever they choose, but not religious 
faith.
Atheism is not any form of religious belief requiring faith by any 
definition. It is merely the title of a worldview which excludes gods of 
any kind. People choose the label so that they may identify with a larger 
group of like minded individuals who agree on at least one thing, the 
probability that god doesn't exist. Many also believe that religion is 
foolish, wrong and hinders progress in science, education, politics and 
human rights.
