comments.text:
+Bink115z I don't need you to tell me what science is. It is evident to me 
that you don't have any idea of what what science is.

Besides, we both know that explaining science is not your goal. What you're 
really attempting to do, rather poorly, is establish science and religion 
as equals.

When I ask you to provide examples (plural), of how science is axiomatic-- 
you give me one equation. One equation, because it contains axioms, doesn't 
illustrate that all of science and math are axiomatic. I will get to your 
example in just a moment...

Here is my definition of axiom: "A self-evident or universally recognized 
truth; a maxim." This is my use of the word. The sun will rise tomorrow. I 
can make this claim without any math or hard evidence-- because it has done 
so for the last several billion years. It is self-evident. It is based on 
history and observation. Evidence. That is a scientific (and also 
mathematic) axiom.

Here is the second definition of axiom: "A self-evident principle or one 
that is accepted as true without proof as the basis for argument; a 
postulate." This is your use of the word. Your use of this definition 
applies to religion and NOT science. You cannot have Christianity without 
Christ. So you accept him, even when there has been no historical evidence 
of his existence beyond the bible-- which is often contradictory. 

Even our uses of the word axiom are not up to the same standards. 

Now. "The proof of the solution to Fermat's last theorem..." Doesn't 
matter. Fermat's theorem is derived from the pythagorean theorem-- for 
which there is nothing axiomatic-- in an attempt to explain things far more 
complicated than simple geography. This doesn't draw into question the 
foundation of science or math at all. Nor M-theory. Why? As we further 
understand particle physics-- the theory and the math will be improved. 
Like Newton did with algebra, and like Einstein did with Newtonian physics. 
It doesn't make it 'wrong.' M-theory and the math used to describe it is 
being constantly improved as our technology and observation of subatomic 
particles imroves. Just because a complex math starts from let n = 
"whatever"... doesn't make the math wrong. Many equations dealing with 
charge and mass begin with this. Why? Because you must begin with a number 
and because the nth term is variable. It says nothing about the validity of 
the math-- but it does say a lot about your understanding of how math 
works. 

A scientific theory is a body of evidence supporting a theory. It doesn't 
mean it is perfect or without gaps or holes, but is a (best) reflection of 
our knowledge of how something works at the time. Science improves on 
theory all the time. If evidence comes about that draws into question a 
theory-- scientists rethink the theory. Does religion do this? Nope. 
Science doesn't claim perfection. Religion does. Religion claims to be the 
truth regardless of how things really work. 

Religion could never hope to discredit science. That is the real truth. 
Religion already claims to have the truth, and nature must conform to it-- 
a true axiom (using the definition you like and not the way I like.)

While, scientific truth conforms to nature. You claimed in an earlier post 
that science and religion are both 'quests for truth.' How can religion be 
a quest for truth when it already proclaims to have an answer? That is not 
a quest but a creed.

Science could and often does discredit the parts of religion that aren't 
true or don't reflect the way that nature really works.

The bible claims that the world has corners. Not true. That a world-wide 
flood happened at one point. Not true- and a claim for which there is no 
actual geologic evidence. That human life began with one woman and one man. 
Not true. That man was created from woman's rib. Unfounded. That bats are 
birds. Not true. That wearing mixed fabrics is sin. Silly. That women 
shouldn't teach or hold authority over a man-- silly and immoral. That if 
you hear a voice in your head that claims to be 'God' that commands you to 
kill-- you are to do so without question. Immoral and troubling. That 
snakes can talk. That God is both unconditional love, but also jealous 
vengeful. How can that be? 

A person is completely entitled to reject the bible on any of these logical 
fallacies, immoral principals or based purely upon the fact that there has 
never been a shred of evidence in support of the supposed 'historical' 
accounts of the bible. Why? Because, the faithful claim that the bible is 
perfect and without error.

Never mind, that if God were all powerful, he could appear at any time and 
reveal himself to each person on earth at the same time. He could quickly 
put all the nonsense to rest any time he wanted to. Which he either doesn't 
care to do, doesn't actually have the power to do, or doesn't exist. 

Finally, back to evidence. If religion is capable of truth. Where is the 
evidence for your truth?
comments.author: Samuel Whitman

existence all the time (out of chance), so thus it must also be possible 
for a vast expanse of atomic subparticles to simultaneously come into 
existence.

According to the multiverse conjecture, anything that can happen (5th 
dimension) will, so thus such a phenomenon would inevitably occur 
some(time/where) in said dimension.

"New" evidence in the field of quantum mechanics (the field people love to 
have no faith in, because it diverts sharply from lines of traditional 
thought and "common sense"), especially pertaining to quantum entanglement, 
shows that things occur in a superimposed state unless observed (i.e. 
Schroedinger's Cat). Everything assumes the properties of waves until 
observed and interacted with, which suggests that consciousness is directly 
tied to all things expressing any properties (including existence).

Following that logic, the multiverse is essentially one independent 
consciousness. Everything around you, seen and unseen, is directly 
connected by quantum entanglement, and is all controlled by this 
consciousness. Those arguing that this consciousness is a "god" of sorts, 
superior to everything else, cannot be right if you merit any of the 
scientific research done in this scientific sub-genre (YOU SHOULD).

Thus everything is one consciousness, one illusion, and nothing really

believe in something like some sort of paradise, ought it then not "exist" 
in our glorious non-existence?

comments.text:
Evolution is the most proved theory in science.  We not only know how it 
works, why it works, where it works, etc. we understand the mechanisms by 
which it works. 

Allow me to explain this in the simplest terms:
Imagine if a group of birds were washed onto a small island during a storm, 
and there are no similar types of birds on the island.  This group of birds 
is not adapted to living on the island and they have a very difficult time 
finding food sources; but even with these difficulties, the birds manage to 
survive, but they don't thrive.  Over time, there are genetic mutations 
that occur within the genes of the birds; some of these mutation don't harm 
or help the bird, some of these mutations could be harmful and cause the 
birds not to survive, but every once in a while a beneficial genetic 
mutation occurs.  In this case, we'll assume that a bird is born with a 
curved beak instead of the usual straight thin beak, and this allows this 
bird an advantage in getting to pollen in the curved flowers commonly found 
on the island.  Because of this, this bird is more successful, better fed, 
and more able to provide resources for it's family and it's reproduction is 
more successful.  Because THIS CHANGE IS ENCODED INTO THE BIRD'S GENES, it 
is able to pass this beneficial trait onto it's offspring.  Due to the 
expression of dominant and recessive genes, at least some of the offspring 
of this bird will also receive this beneficial trait that is NOW ENCODED 
INTO IT'S GENES and passed along to the generations that come after.  
Eventually, only the birds with curved beaks will survive since they are so 
much more successful.  Accumulate these small changes over thousands or 
millions of years, while keeping these groups apart from each other 
(environmental separation into various micro-climates, etc.) so they 
eventually genetically diverge, and you have evolution.

This is exactly the case that Darwin discovered on the Galapagos Islands.  
Samples of what were thought to be a number of different species of birds 
were brought back from the Galapagos; these birds had many different forms, 
different types of beaks, etc. but it was found that they were really all 
descendents of a single small group of birds and these birds had split into 
small groups that adapted into different ecosystems on the islands.  These 
different groups of birds had evolved to have very different features and 
forms, despite the fact that they were all closely related.  This was 
before the science of genetics had been developed and the scientists had 
only their knowledge of the anatomy of different species with which to 
judge this; but they judged correctly.  Genetics has confirmed the 
speciation of this single group of birds into an entire suite of different 
forms; and the genes cannot lie.

Do we know every single detail about the evolution of humans, do we have 
examples of every single transitional form of the various pre-human 
hominids?  No, we do not.  But considering the tendency for natural, 
organic materials to break down and decompose, it's surprising that we have 
ANY remains at all.  So it's not at all surprising that we have not yet 
found the remains of every possible example of pre-human hominid; we're 
lucky to have found ANY.  But what we have discovered fits what we know 
about the genetics.  It's not a perfect picture, but it is almost all the 
way filled in and the parts we do have, shows quite clearly what's in the 
picture.

Oh, and just because the word "theory" is used doesn't mean that it's nor 
proved.  In science, a "theory" is an overall framework that attempts to 
explain a phenomenon, not a guess or hypothesis as in popular culture.  
While some theories are initial and more hypothetical, other theories (such 
as evolution) are still considered "theories" even when they are proven.  
Some people think of a "theory" as being the opposite of a "law"; this is 
not the case.  A theory has to incorporate known laws in order to be 
correct.  An example would be that any theory that attempts to explain how 
gravity works, has to incorporate the known laws of gravity.  The laws of 
gravity tell you nothing about how or why gravity works, just that it 
does.  Whereas a theory of gravity has to explain how and why gravity works 
and it has to account for the laws of gravity existing and incorporate 
them.  Don't be fooled by the, "it's just a theory" line; it's bullshit.

"Atheist evolution"?

I know this won't be productive but I may as well point out that atheism is 
simply non-theism, theism being a positive claim for which there is no 
evidence. Atheism rejects the claim of theism, but that's all. It doesn't 
imply anything beyond that.

Evolution on the other hand is an empirical science. Neither theistic nor 
atheistic. It doesn't care. It is true of course that evolution does 
directly contradict the mythology of many religions, but it doesn't set out 
to do these things. It's simply a fact that what we can determine to be 
true about nature precludes what storybooks claim is true.

comments.text:
+suckittomcat To reword what I meant is if you choose to defy science as 
being true. I would say I exaggerated when I said "full comprehension" but 
even just acknowledging the fact science has proven true. If someone tells 
you something with proven scientific evidence, will you dismiss it due to 
God or will you listen to reason why that something is true. Example being 
fossils are older then creationist stories. Onto another interesting topic 
though since we went on the science part, lets look at the religion 
aspects. one issue with religion and one that I can't understand is 
strictly on the word faith. What is "faith?" The technical definition is: 
(belief or trust: belief in, devotion to, or trust in somebody or 
something, especially without logical proof) If you say faith is something 
else, then how do you keep it uniform within a religion? The key part to me 
in the definition is, "especially without logical proof" I say people have 
to earn my trust, it is not given. I also am a very logical person. I want 
to make sense of things and not just say "God did this so done" Even IF I 
say this was all God's doing. I want to understand every piece of it and 
not just stop at the God part. I dislike any answer that just stops at the 
point where God must have done it so stop looking. I think the opposite, 
lets understand why God did everything he did and try to piece together 
every part of the world. Perhaps god wants us to understand every piece of 
this miraculous world he built. Now I ask, looking at it through that 
perspective. Why is science so bad? We are trying to make sense of a 
beautiful world and why shouldn't we? Even if it disproves some of what we 
"believe" or have "faith" to be true. Wouldn't we rather understand why God 
made ants,bees,people,dogs,cats, and so on so that we can enjoy everything 
the world has to offer?

That was me attempting to make an argument for why people of religion 
should still want and love science. I obviously don't agree on religion but 
to shut your eyes to parts of the world because of it isn't just a 
disservice to yourself, I think you are actually degrading everything that 
you deity built. Faith is a weird concept to me. I can have faith that im 
going to win the lottery or something of that nature but if I went around 
telling everyone I know for sure I am going to win the lottery seems very 
strange. That is how I feel with creationist stories. If you say you have 
evidence for creationist stories then you do not have "faith" because you 
have logical proof. Hence why I get confused when people say they have 
faith and evidence for that faith. The faith is no longer faith.

it means, and second, the evidence is very shaky, usually based on 
anecdote, which simply cannot be tested. When they do try to test stuff 
like out of body experiences, they usually get inconclusive data (ie. The 
subject is unable to discern an object hidden above where they are, which 
they would see if they ever left their body)

"megalithic constructions on the Moon and on Mars"

Okay, here is where I got really confused, I mean, what? Do you have any 
source for that claim?

Again, vague similarities do not mean that these gods actually existed and 
they were all talking to these people. It at best means that these myths 
must have been shared at one point and used as a basis for their own myth. 
It also doesn't explain why these gods clearly aren't active anymore. The 
world didn't end when there were no longer Mayans to perform massive 
sacrifices, Yahweh isn't throwing floods at people because they're not 
sacrificing goats and the lack of wicker men being burned has not affected 
the world in any way.

I've already found Evolution Cruncher. Judging from the fact that it quote 
mines Charles Darwin near the beginning, this is already starting to sound 
like the same old crap. Not only that, but it starts off talking about 
cosmology, which has NOTHING TO DO WITH EVOLUTION. It also flat out lies 
and says that evolution is based on spontaneous generation and larmarkic 
theory, which is just plain wrong. This is seriously already so bad it's 
comical. Frankly, I've only just started reading this and I think I've 
heard enough.

I feel like we're starting to go off in many directions at once, and that 
kind of discussion is usually a slog to maintain, so why don't we narrow 
the topic down a bit?

top_comment.text:
People ought to stop mocking creationists. Not because they are right, but 
because the Big Bang Theory is a theory. A good scientist should understand 
the difference between theory and fact. While there is good evidence that 
the universe was created thus, we are not completely certain. Therefore, 
until it is proven unequivocally true, there is some faith involved in 
accepting the theory. We should at all turns, however, resist the idea that 
ultimate knowledge can be derived from a single text. In short, don't mock 
the faithful because their ideas sound preposterous, simply insist that 
their viewpoints are subjective and not scientific and therefore do not 
have a place in that community.﻿

comments.text:
I'm a fan of argument, so if you're game here it is. I promise to be 
polite. Here it is:

Yes, I know what a scientific theory is. I also know that the Big Bang 
Theory is only the most recent of ideas that explains the formation of the 
universe. I also know, that if a better idea were to come along, science 
would be compelled to accept it. Therefore, I find it unscientific to mock 
faith because to do so is to state, very clearly that there are no other 
explanations. It sounds awfully similar to what creationist theory says.

As to the "If you don't know everything..." argument. Yes, this is a silly 
argument because one doesn't need to know everything to be able to make 
assumptions and solve for x, so to speak. Don't take what I am saying to 
mean just that. Rather, let's put this spin on it, shall we? "Because I 
don't know everything, I must acknowledge the fact, no matter how small it 
may be, that there is a chance I could be wrong." It's important to do so, 
because if we cling to one idea too strongly, we may miss the opportunity 
for a better understanding of our universe later down the road.
comments.author: Ethan

comments.text:
+petion2013 "Evolution is not a science"  You are correct.  What most 
people don't understand, or interpret wrong, is that a "theory" is the 
closest thing to a FACT or something being 100% true that a scientist (or 
any logical person) will call something.  Nothing can ever be proven as 
absolute when dealing with intangible elements....or even tangible elements 
depending how far you want to take this line of thinking.  Am I typing on a 
keyboard right now?  Probably, yes, but there is a chance, no matter how 
remote, (and I hate this analogy but it works for the masses) that I, and 
everyone else, are in The Matrix.  In which case, I'm just in a lifelong 
dream that seems real because it's all I've ever known.  That's why, at 
it's absolute core, nothing can ever really be proven to be 100% fact. 
 But, a "working theory" is the closest thing you can get to "fact" there 
is.  Depending on the theory, like evolution, weather, oceanic events, and 
so on, there's every possibility that there have been billions of 
opportunities for these theories to be proven wrong, and they are batting a 
thousand, without one single failure, ever.........to date.  

That's why I can only chuckle when I hear a theist say that they want the 
"theory" of creationism taught along in science class with the theory of 
evolution.  No, the proper statement would be, "I want the supposition of 
creationism brought up, along with teaching the theory of evolution". 
 Creationism is an entire universe away from ever being called a theory, 
and by its own definition, never can be.

comments.text:
+Modulating Toast Ok, but can you use the contradictions in the bible as 
proof against the christian god?  If you've ever seen Dr Bart Ehrman's 
lecture entitled "Misquoting Jesus" (and if you haven't I recommend you 
youtube it), he essentially explains that, because for 1,500 years the only 
way to make copies of the bible was to do it by hand, mistakes would be 
made on a fairly large level even if a college educated person today 
attempted to make a copy by hand, let alone the literacy levels in past by 
comparison.  That being said, and using some pretty basic math, it's all 
but been proven that almost every word in the modern day bible SHOULD in 
fact have changed at least once, if not more than once, as every new copy 
would carry over the previous errors, and introduce new ones, when were 
then carried over as well, with more new ones added, so on and so on until 
sometime in the early 1700's when the first printing press was invented.  

So, can we really use a source that's essentially known to be completely in 
error from it's original form as "proof" when you find a mistake like a 
contradiction?  Don't get me wrong, I find the likelihood of one religions 
particular god, over the thousands of gods that people have believed in 
over 10's of thousands of years actually being correct to be exceedingly 
infinitesimal, however, for anyone to say "I know for a fact that there is 
no god(s)" makes them just as bad as any theist who says "I know for a fact 
that there IS a god, my god, the christian god".  

That was really my only point, and why I'm a Pragmatic Agnostic Atheist. 
 Agnostic being the root word, and thus primary, with Pragmatic and Atheist 
as prefix and suffix accordingly

comments.text:
+MillionthUsername Neither evolution nor science is atheism. Most 
Christians globally accept evolution, and most people who accept evolution, 
globally, are Christians. They aren't mutually exclusive. You can accept 
evolution and believe in God and Jesus.

Science (or evolution) doesn't assert materialism, or that an intelligence 
wasn't involved. It simply hasn't yet proven an intelligence *was* involved.

We *have* observed natural selection changing species, one famous example 
is the peppered moth. As England industrialized and poured out black soot 
which gradually stained the trees, the peppered moth population evolved to 
be darker to blend in and avoid predators.
You can find thousands of similar examples from all around the world, and 
as the previous poster mentioned, humans have taken control of natural 
selection and directed it, producing *huge* changes to the grey wolf to 
make the chihuahua and all other dog breeds, and huge changes to 
domesticated crops. Compare modern corn to corn from 15,000 years ago.

Before you go calling fields of science 'religion', why don't you educate 
yourself in them?
I've just finished a free online course from Duke University called 
'genetics and evolution' which was really good, I'd definitely recommend 
checking out that or similar courses, from Coursera.org and EdX.org

comments.text:
+MillionthUsername
'' In the very definition of science now, they exclude intelligent agency - 
which is unbelievable hubris and completely at odds with the very notion of 
science. ''

To make a serious claim, one must first present a hypothesis. With a solid 
hypothesis established ( meaning you present what you expect will happen 
during your testing phase. how you plan to test it, and what these resoults 
should prove ), the work may begin. Through testing, documentation of 
resoults and retesting, the hypothesis can in itself be tested. When in the 
testers opinion the claims of this hypothesis have been met, a paper is 
written and offered to the scientific community.

The Community then it turn, follows said paper to conduct testing of their 
own. Through the same, and corrolating tests so to determine if the 
resoults come out the same. If the resoults are the same, it is only then 
the making of a scientific Theory.

Until such a point, any opinions, well wishing or exclemations on a subject 
are nothing more then hot air ( specially if you use the Bible or any form 
of religious document as a source for irrefutable evidence ). And *that* my 
friend, is how science works in a nut shell.

And that is also why, Intelligent Design, Creation, or what ever it was, 
is, and will be labened in the future, is complete hogwash.

taught as a "fact," and not even a theory anymore.

"You really need to educate yourself on the basics of how this works, if 
you think natural selection is a random process."

Back to the parsing. It's not random??? Mutations are not random???? Then 
why are they called mutations? You expect every mutation which occurs? 
Every mutation is part of a plan? What are you talking about here???? If 
you're going to parse this, then don't bother. I don't even want to waste 
my time arguing over something so stupid as how "random" applies to 
mutations but not the "process" of natural selection. That's a word game.

Natural selection is a catch-all for whatever happens in nature to a group 
of living things, whether they survive or fail to survive, or whether 
traits are passed on or not. It's not a power in nature to create new 
organs and new genetic code - which is what is being claimed for it. That 
claim is absurd in the extreme. Organisms are already existing and 
surviving and complete when "natural selection" is said to work. There's is 
nothing that drives forward any "process" of massive change and 
re-structuring. That is all a belief system. If it were not, you would be 
able to demonstrate it. You can't. So stop making the claim. Call it a 
belief because that's what it is. You believe that this power of creation 
is in nature. That's your religion. It isn't mine, so stop calling your 
religion "science."

comments.text:
First, the question of how life originated is not a question that the 
theory of evolution addresses. Theories in science have scopes - they ever 
even attempt to explain things within clear limits, and leave things 
outside those limits for other theories to explain.

Thus the question of how life originated from non-life is a question for 
abiogenesis models, and for the theory of evolution, it doesn't MATTER how 
life got here. From the perspective of the theory of evolution, you could 
believe that life was deposited on Earth by the Easter Bunny, and you 
wouldn't be contradicting anything in the theory of evolution, because the 
theory of evolution is not a theory of everything, it  is a theory that 
explains how the diversity of life we observe came about from initially 
simple life.

If you want to discuss abiogenesis, that is fine, but don't confuse it with 
evolution.

You quoted me thus:
"Evolution does contain random elements, but it's the very non-random 
process of natural selection that accounts for the order and complex 
functional structure of life."

And then you replied to this quote by:

"Mutations are not random? What, do you guys parse "random" now into 
complete meaninglessness?"

How about reading the very bit you quoted again, this time with thought? I 
began the sentence with "evolution does contain random elements". Mutations 
ARE what I'm referring to here. They are one of the random elements.

So no, I'm not saying that mutations are not random, I am saying that 
NATURAL SELECTION is not random, and it is the natural selection that acts 
on mutations, that explain the complexity of life, not the random mutations 
themselves.

You really need to educate yourself on the basics of how this works, if you 
think natural selection is a random process.

I am off to work now, so I'll have to cut it here. I'll return to the rest 
later, if others have not satisfactorily addressed your points by then.

comments.text:
+MillionthUsername Why, yes. All life is related. Though gorillas and 
cucumbers are so distantly related that you'd have to go back more than one 
and a half billion years to find the common ancestor between gorillas and 
cucumbers.

That common ancestor would of course be the same common ancestor shared by 
all animals and all plants, not just gorillas and cucumbers.

The more closely related two species are, the more shared genetic 
structures they have, and the more they share non-functional features that 
could not be explained by "common design" at all; like the EVRs that 
HeyHeyHarmonicaLuke explained above.

You can reconstruct the family tree describing the relations of species 
simply by looking at the genes of those species. The tree constructed in 
this way matches the tree constructed from other, independent lines of 
evidence, like fossils, morphological comparison and geographic locations 
of species.

Several different lines of evidence converge to give one consistent 
picture, and that picture is common descent. This is why common descent is 
as close to universally accepted among life scientists, as any theory can 
ever hope to be.

comments.text:
Cutri can I tell you about one of the ways the family tree is mapped using 
genetics? ERV codes:
Retroviruses are viruses that insert their DNA into ours, then like regular 
viruses, hijack our cellular machinery to replicate themselves. Often they 
lay dormant for a long time, and often they entirely fail to activate or 
are harmless, and the host cell survives with its new section of inserted 
endogenous DNA. If this happens in a somatic cell, this vanishes within the 
generation, but if it happens in a sex cell (sperm, egg, recently 
fertilized egg) it can be passed on to all the cells of the body and down 
through the generations as a permanent addition to the genome.
Some types of endogenous retrovirus codes (ERVs) insert at specific sites 
in the genome, but some are known to insert in a random spot, e.g. after 
any 'gtta', of which there are millions. When one of these randomly placing 
ERV codes is in the same location in all the members of two populations, it 
amounts to very strong evidence that the ERV infection happened in a common 
ancestor to both populations.
With millions of potential insertion sites multiplied by millions of 
different retroviruses out there, it is astronomically unlikely for any two 
organisms to share the same randomly placing ERV code in the same spot in 
the genome, and it not be the result of inheritance- and yet all life 
shares some randomly placing ERV codes, the most ancient ones. Others are 
shared by groups of families of animals, painting the family tree in 
extraordinary detail and matching the family trees mapped by other 
independent methods of investigation, like comparative anatomy.

comments.text:
+joe cole
 I have no idea wtf you're talking about. But intelligence is obviously 
more important than survival of the fittest. The only reason mankind is at 
the top is because of intelligence.
Here's a few  facts of the matter, I hope you read and don't make your own 
assumptions without taking in some home truths.

1).“Survival of the fittest” is NOT the guiding principal of individual 
behaviour. It is the biological mechanism which determines the adaptability 
of a species over time, NOT individuals within their own lifetime. 
Evolution happens gradually over hundreds of millions of years. Random 
mutations in the DNA code do not always produce positive results. Mutations 
are not always beneficial because evolution is unguided; it has no 
foresight. Natural selection builds upon mutations that produce adaptations 
which are beneficial in specific areas, just as it cancels out mutations 
that are detrimental in others. This explains why 99% of all life that has 
ever lived on Earth is now extinct

2). Evolution does not propose origins of life. Evolution does not seek to 
answer the question of how the first multicellular organisms appeared. It 
describes how they evolved once they formed, not how they formed in the 
first place. Abiogenesis is in no way related to Darwinian evolution

3).  The genetic evidence of natural selection is compelling enough proof 
of evolution without any evidence from fossils whatsoever. If Darwin had 
never lived, we would still have eventually discovered naturally occurring 
selection mechanisms in our DNA. If there were no fossils in the fossil 
record, whatsoever, the evidence of evolution in our genes would still be a 
fact. Genetics does not require the evidence from the fossil record in any 
way shape or form. Lateral gene transfer is a major mechanism in 
prokaryotic genome evolution. Gene theory and palaeontology are two 
completely separate areas of study that just so happen to support each 
other. Independently acquired, mutually corroborative evidence is the heart 
and soul of the theory of evolution. To disprove one, you must disprove the 
other, yet each set of evidences are intrinsically linked, while being 
independently ascertained

4). Beyond a shadow of doubt, human DNA and chimpanzee DNA are 98% 
identical.

5). Not a single living organism that has ever been discovered shows any 
sign, whatsoever, of having evolved by non-Darwinian means. If there were, 
the scientific method is precisely designed to discover it. There are no 
known species of any living organism anywhere on Earth that can not be 
fully described by evolution theory.

6). Darwinism when applied to free market economics, is a flawed form of 
capitalism and gives rise to a supreme irony. Free market theory has been 
shown time and again to favour the rich to the detriment of the poor. Every 
single European and American government who has applied Darwinism to their 
economic policy, has been forced, at some point, to apply regulations to 
the market, so as to counterbalance this unwanted effect. Despite this, in 
the American system of governance, free market ultra-capitalism remains to 
be the fundamental ideological difference between predominantly evangelical 
smaller state conservatives, who favour it, and predominantly non-religious 
liberal democrats who oppose it. Darwinian economics is synonymous with 
conservatism, not liberalism.

7) . Darwin was wrong about a great many things. As were many of the people 
who supported his theory when it was first published. There are examples 
throughout history of scientists making huge mistakes which have led 
science down blind alleys of investigation, sometimes for hundreds of 
years. But the beauty of the scientific method, is that these mistakes 
always come to light. Darwin did not set his theories in stone, rather he 
hoped that future generations of naturalists would DISPROVE his many 
claims. Since then, this is what biologists, palaeontologists, geneticists, 
chemists, anthropologists and every other discipline in science has sought 
to achieve. We have yet to find any compelling evidence that might falsify 
any aspect of natural selection, despite that the scientific method is 
geared towards doing exactly that.

8)Here is exactly what Darwin wrote in “Decent of Man”, followed by the 
text as it appears in the pro-Intelligent Design film, “Expelled”:
"With savages, the weak in body or mind are soon eliminated; and those that 
survive commonly exhibit a vigorous state of health. We civilised men, on 
the other hand, do our utmost to check the process of elimination. We build 
asylums for the imbecile, the maimed and the sick; we institute poor-laws; 
and our medical men exert their utmost skill to save the life of every one 
to the last moment. There is reason to believe that vaccination has 
preserved thousands, who from a weak constitution would formerly have 
succumbed to small-pox. Thus the weak members of civilised societies 
propagate their kind. No one who has attended to the breeding of domestic 
animals will doubt that this must be highly injurious to the race of man. 
It is surprising how soon a want of care, or care wrongly directed, leads 
to the degeneration of a domestic race; but excepting in the case of man 
himself, hardly anyone is so ignorant as to allow his worst animals to 
breed"

And now the edited version, popular on pro-creationist websites:

"With savages, the weak in body or mind are soon eliminated. We civilised 
men, on the other hand, do our utmost to check the process of elimination. 
We build asylums for the imbecile, the maimed and the sick. Thus the weak 
members of civilised societies propagate their kind. No one who has 
attended to the breeding of domestic animals will doubt that this must be 
highly injurious to the race of man. Hardly anyone is so ignorant as to 
allow his worst animals to breed."

*The original version of this article incorrectly used the age of the 
universe as the age of the Earth.

comments.text:
+zombiemurloc I don't think you quite understood my point.

You're applying a property (being created) to a concept that SPECIFICALLY 
proposes an uncreated God. You're ignoring the premise of the concept, 
which is a fallacious approach to the argument.

"You can't have something without a creator" isn't the correct way to 
define a (proper) Christian viewpoint: "You can't have creation without a 
creator" does far more justice to the religion's viewpoint. Why? Because 
God, by the Christian definition, is not a part of creation. You say, "God 
exists. He must have been created!" But you ignore that by definition, god 
PRE-exists. Meaning, he would be exempt from creation.

I assume you proposed this for argument sake, but the universe can't have 
"always existed", because that undermines the fundamental law of cause and 
effect. A rule which applies to "creation", as it were. According to the 
theological view, the universe is "creation". God is not. What you're 
trying to do is apply this law of creation to God! How is it logical to 
conclude that God, who allegedly formed creation, is submissive to his OWN 
invention of cause and effect? Why must HE be subject to the properties of 
creation, provided he, by basic definition, transcended and shaped it? 
You're confining a supposedly almighty being to the human condition. That's 
silly.

Your application of "sky man" only leads me to assume you have a very 
limited, simplistic conception of Christianity/theology as a whole, 
reinforced by unfortunate (but understandably numerous) encounters with 
woefully ignorant Christians. Don't get me wrong, most Christians exhibit 
even worse simplicity.
comments.author: Christian Pickhardt

comments.text:
+KiaraTheMysterKid
No, you don't seem to understand. Different claims aren't equally valid.

If person A claims that pi, defined as the ratio between the radius and 
circumference of a circle, is between 3.1 and 3.2 based on repeatable 
experiments with for instance a length of rope, and person B claims that 
it's 7 because 7 is a holy number to him/her and circles are perfectly 
round and thus holy, then those claims are not equally valid.

Given the above, person A is easily justified in calling person B a 
"nutjob" because there's demonstrably no connection between the supposed 
holyness of the number 7 and the ratio between the radius and circumference 
of a circle, yet person B still claims it to be so. The justification does 
not lie in person A's views/opinions, but in his/her ability to back up 
his/her claims. Thus person B isn't able to "easily flip the table" and 
call person A a "nutjob" - person B has no justifications for that what so 
ever.

Do you understand now how your point is completely invalid?

In 1953, the Miller–Urey experiment was performed that simulated the

comments.text:
-> *Ronald Kelly*
*I am sorry virginia, yep that is probably a broad brush approach, even 
though I never hear about atheists getting together to to charity work as a 
group,*
Atheists groups always seemed weird to me, since organizing around a 
non-thing is a bit... out of character, maybe?

Anyway, there are atheists organizations that do charity (e.g. Foundation 
Beyond Belief), and countless secular ones, but my point was that many 
atheists are involved in charity as *individuals*, and with both secular 
charity *and* religious orgs (I've done both. The cause is more important 
than the label. But I admit I give a bit more scrutiny to the religious 
ones to avoid inadvertently giving to cults. Sometimes, it isn't clear).

*plus I was seeking to undo a common notion that atheists say 'christians 
are all about the money' which absolutely false so I was responding to that 
idiotic claim*

Some *are* about the money. Some are in jail for frauds related directly to 
their religious activities. Some are full-fledge con men. I'm sorry, but 
christianity has a very bad rep regarding that. Probably underserved in 
many cases (I've known monks who obviously don't care about money, most 
priests or ministers I"ve met didn't either). 

I've always wondered how Jesus would have reacted to the circus and money 
machines some denominations have become, given the way he properly pwned 
those merchants at the Temple. Now, that's the Jesus I like, btw. The 
"'don't give me bs" one.

*By the way why would atheists who believe in evolution even want to help 
the weak, needy, disabled? If it is a philosophy of survival of the fittest 
why would evolutionists have any reason to undo evolution and just let the 
weak die so the strong can carry on*?

Three reasons:

First, we're as good (or bad) persons as you can be. The difference is that 
the ethic comes from ourselves, our family, our experience rather than a 
dogma. You have a very skewed view of "evolutionists". We certainly do not 
condon eugenism. As explained below, evolution isn't about condoning anyway.

Second, *Evolution is not a philosophy*. It's a scientific theory. 
Observing that change and diversification is partly based on the ability 
for a species to survive and thrive in a given environment is an 
observation. Saying it would imply some sort of ethic is like saying 
virologists want everyone to die from Hepatitis C or the Spanish Flu, or 
vulcanologists want the planet to go boom.

Third, in case you haven't noticed, we work against evolution constantly. 
Everytime someone design a new antibiotic or antiviral, a new genic 
therapy, they work *against* evolution, using their knowledge of evolution 
as a weapon. Since, of course, to be able to have a modicum of control, we 
need to know its mechanisms as best as possible.

You seem to see evolution as a dogma. As though we worshipped mother nature 
and submitted to her will. We don't. We only study it. And we do that 
partly to satisfy our curiosity (i.e. thirst for knowledge), but also to 
*help* people by finding cures and such.

*I remember a movie I was shown in high school about a ship that sank and 
there were people in a life boat and on floating debree and with limited 
supplies he had to choose who would have the best chance of survival so he 
started getting rid of the old and to young to help etc etc. Why would they 
show that to kids if not to give the impression that some people are 
expendable, evolutions trademark*

I don't know where you get the idea that "evolutionists" would kill 
expendable people in the name of the evolution dogma. I'm sorry, but it 
reeks of misinformation and propaganda (not on your part, but with you as 
the victim).

Finally, the quotes I used on purpose. There are no such things as 
"evolutionists", no more than there are "gravitists" or "general 
relativists" or "Thales theoremists". *There is no ideology in scientific 
theories* (or math theorems). Only observations, facts, reasoning and 
deductions.

Partially accurate. You're missing two key points that invalidate your 
claim.

1. Almost any natural disaster can result in burial. Earthquake. Flood. 
Landslide. Avalanche. Tornado. Eruption. Animals and instincts are buried 
all the time.

2. If your "global catastrophe" hypothesis were true, the majority of 
fossils would date to around the same era. They don't. They vary from 
billions of years old to only a few thousand.

There are many examples of multiple fossil forms found in small areas, 
particularly in places with active volcanoes, wherein the fossils are in 
multiple sedimentary layers that are dated tens of thousands of years apart.

I suggest you study science from scientists -- not creationists. Ken Ham's 
Biology for Dummies seems to have left you with quite a few misconceptions.
comments.author: AntitheistPOV

the method for the larger/general preservation of fossils.  The other point

comments.text:
+el flesh
*"I entirely know what you mean about a pink unicorn. I knew about this 
argument in another form from 20 years ago when I was in Uni studying it. I 
submit that when you disprove claim after claim about a fantasy creature, 
you disprove the creature. Stupid. "*
Then I don't get what the problem is. I agree.

*"Uneducated people can be manipulated to kill by psychpaths was [your] 
point." then why didn't you simply STATE it? Clairvoyance does not actually 
exist, you know."*
Maybe because the language skills of a person usually only go as far as a 
certain point without actually living in a country where it is spoken. 
English is my 3rd language with the least hours of use, it's not perfect.

*"I ignored your point about the thousands in a religion that don't kill, 
because they have no problem causing non lethal harm such as can be found 
in a perusal of the well documented 'God is not Great'. You're an apologist 
for those thousands."*
That's a bit severe. Not all "have no problem" causing such harm. Also, I 
don't defend non-lethal damage, I just don't know what to do about such 
people, other than speak up when I see such injustice and hope others do 
the same.

*"I couldn't count the number of professionally paid Scientists I have 
talked to over 30 years.  There are enough to say that absolutely NONE of 
them have ever come out with 'stupid shit'. If you actually are a 
professionally paid Scientist, then, rest assured, you are the first."*
So you absolutely believe that no scientist believes in false things, 
worded or not?

*"This, exactly, is bullshit: "False, mental illness has been treated like 
that for over a century if not more." BULLSHIT. As I said, mental illness 
has been treated more and more differently during the last 40 years, I have 
seen it."*
From now and back isn't the timeframe I'm talking about. I'm talking about 
the time BEFORE. I know it has changed in modern times. I would even think 
someone that cares about others being "chauvenistic assholes" would see 
this, as the mental health sector has been particularly unkind to women. 

*"Your original posit that medical Science does wrong things due to 
unchanging protocols might be right, but you have yet to prove it."*
I used medical science because it's the most "sticky" to change its 
protocols even when evidence is there to do things differently, unlike 
physics for example. I know it does change - just not as fast as the 
evidence does (was my point).

*"I said that women have the right to decide if they want a c-section or 
not"*
And how is this different from what I said? I said, after copy pasting: 
"Women DON'T always choose, was my point. There is a 4 times increased risk 
of death for the child in the world by c-section birth and a 3 times 
increased risk of death for the mother. If it's elective, then I don't 
mind, as it is indeed the mother's choice."
As an anecdote - my mother was never asked when giving birth to my brother, 
she was told that they would do it, even though it wasn't a particularly 
high risk birth.

*"Even at 4% more fatalities, that is firstly WORLDWIDE as you reported, 
therefore not reflecting the actual case in any given country"*
I know - I was there when I said it.

*"secondly that is up to the woman in question to decide - not you. 
Asshole."*
You like insulting people, don't you? I don't know what the point is - do 
you become more right the more you insult someone? I never stated anything 
otherwise. I do think women should chose, and not be told to get one as 
often in many countries. They should be given the proper information, and 
make the decision with their doctor(s). If you actually read my posts you 
would have seen this.

*"I am very hostile against a chauvenistic asshole like yourself."*
Again, what the fuck? You don't know me or my values other than the ones 
I've shown here and they don't warrant that response - at least not the 
"chauvenistic" one. Also, you've made some image in your head about me 
wanting to outlaw c-sections, because "I want to cause women pain". 
Nonsense - I never stated any such thing.

*"You protect people's rights to be born and raised into ignorance, fear 
and to subvert their freedom of choice and sexual identity."*
I agree, it's not good that people raise their children with an oppressive 
religion. I can attest to this being gay, raised in a very Christian 
dominated country in a religious household. Thankfully, my family isn't 
religious anymore. However, if you want a truely free society, you cannot 
ban religion, only protect innocent people from the dangers of it, like 
punishing faith healers or whatever.
By the looks of your respones you want it banned? Or what do you suggest?

*"ADULTS who are educated and fully in control of their minds and rationale 
are the only ones who are free to choose religion."*
Who decides when people can chose their religion? You? Do you want a panel 
of "free minded and rational" judges to make sure people are sufficiently 
schooled to chose their religion? Would that disqualify my "craftsman" (not 
sure what the right word is in English) parents from chosing a religion, as 
they aren't academics?

*"In protecting this system of child and feminine abuse, you are the same 
type of scum as those who perpetrate it. "*
Yes, because you know exactly what I do in my day to day life and have an 
intimate knowledge of my psyche. LOL - and you talk about evidence ruling, 
when clearly you are ruled by emotions yourself.

+el flesh
*"No, Lemonz1989, you have Scientific proof AGAINST a pink unicorn given 
several principles of evolution, given the fact that mythology is a 
pre-Science tool for explaining fantastic fantasies or else exaggerations 
of a real phenomenon. The birth defect goat with one malformed horn in the 
middle of its forehead from an uneducated fishing village is eventually a 
powerful stallion Unicorn seen that came from Athens."*
You have no idea what I'm talking about, do you? The invisible pink unicorn 
is an argument used by atheists. Richard Dawkins uses it often. It has 
nothing to do with "actual" unicorns.

*"Any Scientist accepts that if Jesus himself appears out of thin air and 
proves his magics undeniably dozens of times, then Science was wrong about 
him not existing. But finding a breeding population of pink Unicorns in 
what is left of virgin forests would be more likely. Most of the uneducated 
and brainless public sees that above statement and immediately defaults to 
"OH SCIENCE ADMITS IT COULD BE WRONG =  JESUS IS PROVEN!" Bullshit."*
I don't see what the point of this argument is. I agree with you. You are 
very hostile against arguments where I have said that I agree with you.

*"You most certainly implied 2%: "It could just be that organized religions 
are often ruled by actual psychopaths that have no problems with killing, 
and psychopaths constitute around 1 - 2% of the population, so there is no 
shortage of them around." You were arguing AGAINST my point about religion 
KILLING people. It's hardly a strawman argument to say that you should do 
your research to explain why your account differs from every other one on 
record."*
I said that religions are most often ruled by psychopaths, not that only 
psychopaths kill. Uneducated people can be manipulated to kill by 
psychpaths was my point. That can be in the name of whatever supernatural 
thing or political ideology. You also ignored my point about every 
religious zealot that kills, there are thousands of people in the same 
religion that don't.

*"It's hardly a strawman to state it's 'your' bible if you write in 
protection of it."*
I don't protect "my" bible. I think it's a bag of shit. I protect peoples' 
right to have a religion, because I'm against thought crimes.

*"In talking about Science, you made several blanket statements :  "Even 
smart people that are more skeptical than average will believe in stupid 
shit." "There is much humans believe that is a crock of shit, not just 
religion. There is probably science we take for granted now, that is a 
crock of shit, " So, yes, you DID indeed say that. I haven't heard any 
'crocks of shit' said by any actual Scientist. Only religious ones, who 
cannot actually be called Scientists, therefore."*
I know what I said, you just didn't adress my point when you said: "I have 
never EVER heard any Scientist I ever spoke to come out with "stupid shit". 
 Your blanket statement has no supporting evidence."
I didn't say that scientists always say stupid shit, I said all people 
believe in things that aren't true = stupid shit.
It's common sense to know that people will believe in false things, even 
scientists. Besides, how many scientists have you talked to?
If you want one example, then there is Linus Pauling - two times nobel 
prize winner together with many other awards. He was not a medical doctor, 
yet he promoted the alternative treatment regimes of megavitamin therapy 
and orthomolecular medicine, and said either all or almost all diseases 
were caused by nutritional deficiencies - which is false.

_"BULLSHIT. Mental illness treatment HAS changed DRASTICALLY in the last 
FORTY years, let alone century. Maybe not in your country, but definitely 
in mine, in the Mental hospital where I have been contracted to WORK. That 
might be anecdotal, but there are loads of resources on the internet 
PROVING otherwise.
If you're going to make BULLSHIT statements, you will be called on them. 
That is not a strawman, that is response to STATEMENTS that are BULLSHIT.
Diabetics treatment has indeed changed ALOT in my lifetime, and that proves 
you once again - WRONG."_
What exactly is bullshit? I never said mental illness treatment hasn't 
changed. It was violent and unproductive up until the last few decades. 
Before that it was basically stagnant for over a century. All sorts or 
"unnormal" behaviors were treated as diseases. I know it has changed now - 
and it's about time too. In my country it was still fine to forcefully lock 
up people without much reason at all only 30 years ago.
Diabetes has changed in your lifetime of course. It has even changed in 
mine, in the last 10 years I've had it. I went from insulin pens to insulin 
pump in just a few years, however, I've met people that have been in the 
same treatment for decades up until the 70s. So, I never said it hadn't. I 
said it was stagnant with blatently wrong information for decades until 
around the 1960s.

*"As for c-sections, (which are in fact considered SAFE) you prove you are 
nothing but a chauvenistic prick. I should like to shove a football up your 
ass sideways and see if you choose to endure it a second time or go for a 
c-section insertion instead. That is not a strawman attack made to defeat 
your point, I have done that in my previous post; that is me telling you 
that you are indeed an ASSHOLE who tries to give women pain. I have seen 
the results of denial of c-sections by SHITBAGS like you."*
So you want women to be forced to get c-sections against their will, 
because they are "safe"? Great... And you call ME a chauvenistic prick...

*"Religion KILLS people and spreads misery. If you are going to defend it, 
it makes you part of the problem and NOT the cure."*
Yes, I'm the problem when you try to force its extinction against peoples' 
will. I don't defend religion, I defend people against thought crimes. I 
would never defend a religious person killing or being violent, I'm against 
blashemy laws and I don't think religion should take precedent over 
evidence, like "faith healing" or other BS. I don't see how I'm the problem 
here.

week and hundreds of useless words, but you made it.

replace science, even though religious people may or may not have.

create some kind of ambiguity here?
In the world of facts and figures, science stands above all. In the world 
of spirituality and meaning of life, religion stands above all.

But you're not alone. You have showed to be very black/white in your 
thinking, very dogmatic. One just has to look up to your previous comments. 
So unfortunately for you, you sound as stupid as the average religious 
fanatic, really you do.  Except that you use science as your cover. It's

comments.text:
1. Wrong. Abiogenesis is the natural process by which life rose from 
ORGANIC materials. Most likely in stagnant pools of water.

2. Steven Hawking did say that. Nothing in Evolution contradicts the 2nd 
Law of Thermodynamics. The 2nd Law says that heat will not spontaneously 
flow from a colder body to a warmer one or, equivalently, that total 
entropy in a closed system will not decrease. This does not prevent 
increasing order because: 

i. the earth is not a closed system; sunlight (with low entropy) shines on 
it and heat (with higher entropy) radiates off. This flow of energy, and 
the change in entropy that accompanies it, can and will power local 
decreases in entropy on earth.

ii. entropy is not the same as disorder. Sometimes the two correspond, but 
sometimes order increases as entropy increases. (Aranda-Espinoza et al. 
1999; Kestenbaum 1998) Entropy can even be used to produce order, such as 
in the sorting of molecules by size (Han and Craighead 2000).

iii. even in a closed system, pockets of lower entropy can form if they are 
offset by increased entropy elsewhere in the system.
In short, order from disorder happens on earth all the time. 

3. Cosmic Inflation is an easy fix to the Horizon problem. This was 
recently confirmed during a project known as BICEP2 last week. (Keep an eye 
out on the Nobel Prize scene).

4. What the fuck do you think Evolution is? How on earth could The Theory 
of Evolution, which details the fact that genetic mutations of species are 
passed on birth, explain the origin of stars?

If you have anything else to say, make sure it's backed up with 
peer-reviewed evidence. Failure to do so will result in you being ignored 
and ridiculed elsewhere on the World Wide Web.

Hey Harley, you have to remember that there are tens of thousands of 
different sects/branches/offshoots of Christianity, and within those 
Churches there are hundreds of thousands of differing opinions, beliefs,

As for my 1 in a million belief, i believe that pure religion and pure 
science are the same thing. People love to attribute mystical 
characteristics to God which contradict the "laws of nature and the 
universe". I personally believe that God works within the framework of the 
natural order of things. Similar to how talking over radio waves would have 
been seen as witchcraft in ancient history, i believe that our 
understanding of science and religion are still very much in their infant 
stages, and that as we continue to learn more about both, they will 
eventually come together into the single entity we call by one name: truth.

Now if that "truth" ends up being that God is a cyborg robot from planet X, 
or that there is no God at all, or that God is closer to the traditional 
Christian view, then so be it. As for myself, so far everything we have 
learned scientifically fits perfectly with my interpretation of scripture. 
(note the "my interpretation". People believe all sorts of crazy things 
based on the same sources)

comments.text:
+anon
I'll address your points in order:

Theory and hypothesis: Yes, I realize hypothesises are derived from 
rationalism, and if evidence in favor of the hypothesis is observed 
numerous time it becomes a scientific theory. All that is clear to me, and 
certainly I would not be interchanging words if this was a scientific panel 
debate. But this is YouTube. So let's not let semantics get in the way of 
the crux of the issue here, which is that even if a hypothesis is proven 
again and again, new evidence can still come along down the line which 
changes the whole theory or disregards it alltogether. Lots of creationists 
would consider science an "unstable" source of knowledge because it seems 
to be in constant change. Now, moving on, I looked up your reference 
"Evolution is a Winner - for Breakthroughs and Prizes", and I found the 
ncse.com webpage, where the author clearly states that "by his criteria", 
an "understanding of evolution is neccessary in 47 of 50 cases". Which is 
far from as matter-of-fact as you present it in your argument. Either I 
have looked up the wrong site for your source (let me know if I have), or 
you are intentionally being dishonest to prove your point.

Moving on: Are all theories bad because some theories are flawed? No, 
certainly not, and certainly nobody claimed anything like that. However, a 
few "bad apples" in a group, can easily appear to undermine the whole 
group, from the standpoint of an outside observer who may not realize the 
depth and diversity within the group itself. Collectivism maybe, but that 
is the reality one must accept. In my opinion it's absurd to expect people 
to debate a spesific piece of scientific research, without being able to 
touch on science itself from a broader point of view. It cannot be done, 
this is why, for instance the 'politization' of the global warming issue is 
something that has inevitably led to politization of science itself, 
indeed, with the IPCC scandals etc.

Now, unfortunately, it's not just global warming science that people find 
problematic. Corporate science at a whole is something one should be very 
wary off, because there is a clear monetary incentive that often undermines 
scientific truth. The majority of scientists work in private institutions, 
so I would consider this a pretty big problem. I'm not just talking about 
"scientifically proven" ways to lose fat and gain muscle, but things like 
"GMO's are automatically safe, even without long-term testing, because we 
say they are". And pharmaceutical research. For instance, what do you feel 
about the lipid hypothesis still not being proven, but being used as the 
de-facto way to treat peple with high cholesterol? What do you fell about 
so called Monsanto-science, where dishonest 'scientists' utilize the weight 
of 'science' in order to push their own agenda upon people or increase 
their own bottom line? They are able to do this, precisely because science 
is something that is given too much weight these days, and when you're in a 
debate and someone slams some scientific research on the table, everyone is 
immediately expected to shut up, or be labeled ignorant of science. I think 
this is a very dangerous way of thinking because it amounts to blindly 
trusting what any authority tells you, and in the long-term the outcomes 
cannot possibly be good. Indeed it can also lead to scientists themselves 
being shot down. There's plenty of examples where scientists have been 
bullied out of the field because their findings were so "absurd" and didn't 
fit with the current status quo, but have years later been proven to be 
correct.

But it's not just the "do not question me"-attitude of scientists that is a 
problem. In fact, I think science itself is the height of ivory tower 
thinking. Because it's based on the belief that somehow our rational 
process has the power to dominate utterly the biological imperative of the 
cognitive constructs that give you "what is real". It is absurd that our 
generation somehow believes that our perception of reality is somehow 
derived exclusively from strict scientific observation and rational 
dicipline - and not obtained by ourself, the same way that every generation 
before us has done since the beginning of times. Indeed, our paradigm of 
science do face vast limitations. Wittgenstein pointed to a way out of this 
actually, but it was rejected by western academica as too radical and 
damaging to the current paradigm of analysis. Look it up.

Anyways, this is getting too long. I will quickly address your remaining 
points:
*if species A was the ancient ancestor of both B and C, will you find 
either fossilized B or C in the same period as A?* Let me turn the question 
around. If you find fossilized species A in one period and fossilized 
species B and C in another period, does that imply common descent? Isn't 
common descent implied from DNA-data, then confirmed by time period 
separation?

*Test of abiogenesis* Yes, I know about the Miller-Urey experiment. It did 
not form all amino acids. 9 out of 20 amino acids were absent, and it 
formed a massive amount of hydrocarbons. Now, find me some evidence that 
free amino acids can rearrange themselves into self-replicating molecules 
in an atmosphere full of hydrogen cyanide, hydrogen sulfide and 
hydrocarbons (all very toxic to most living organisms today) and we might 
have some very weak evidence, but evidence nontheless.

*Test of macroevolution* I'm well aware of specitation, however I wouldn't 
consider specitation which occurs under controlled laboratory conditions to 
be particularily strong evidence. However I know it has been observed in 
nature and will accept that fact. However macroevolution in a broader scale 
of the type "dinosaurs to birds" as you say, is something I would really 
like to see. As for fossils, I've already been through that previously. If 
it was such a surefire piece of evidence, why isn't every geological 
formation and every stratum full of intermediate links? Answer me that and 
maybe I'll buy into it.

*Scientific theories are not dogma.* Here you present numerous interesting 
points. Coming from economics myself, I can definitely tell you that any 
"community" will not work quite as you say here. For instance, are you 
saying there can never be collusive efforts amongst scientific 
communitites? Can there never be group-mentality, cognitive biases etc. 
inherent in research? Will competetive forces neccessarily wipe out the 
"bad" science? How long does this take? I think the IPCC and climate gate 
is a perfect example of the inherent 'irrationality' that can sometimes 
present itself accross the entire field. I think also that most scientists 
have very narrow fields of interest, and in each field there are a few 
dominate scientists who can and probably will affect the entire field, even 
if they sometimes are wrong. I'm guessing that scientific communities, like 
most, suffer from hierarchial structures. In addition, scientists who 
specialize would then know very little about the science *outside* their 
own field. For instance, you say 88% of scientists agree on global warming? 
What type of scientists are included in that figure? What relevancy would 
it have that for instance a cardiologist believes in global warming? How 
much does he know about the processes behind it? How much would an 
astrophysicist know? I'm sure you get the point.
comments.author: iCookie1

comments.text:
+iCookie1 >>"Your head is buried so far up your ass, you're gonna need a 
Irish tug of war team to pull it out."

How do you know one mere tug of war team -- as opposed to, say, an adult 
African elephant -- would be sufficient for such a feat? Have you 
physically inspected the exact condition of my rear end before extruding 
such a precise prediction? A scientist would have checked first!

Why the personal attacks? Have I used ad hominem, even once, or are you 
accustomed to indiscriminate name calling? It'd be ironic if you were 
Christian: "Why do you look at the speck that is in your brother's eye, but 
do not notice the log that is in your own eye?" I don't see a need to 
assume that anyone who likes science is out to get you, just as I should 
not have to assume that anyone who is religious has an agenda to attack me 
(well, maybe depends on the religion).

I will try to respond to each point in detail:

Theory and hypothesis: using these words interchangeably in casual 
conversation is perfectly normal, but doing so in a discussion of science 
will likely confuse the audience -- in science, hypothesis is an idea, 
whereas a theory is an idea which has already survived tests of the 
scientific method, meaning that it has already been accepted and is 
therefore no longer hypothetical. To paraphrase Ken Miller, an evolutionary 
biologist who happens to be Christian, "in science, theory is an even 
higher form of understanding than facts", because a theory is able to tie 
facts together in an elegant way. In other words, the theory of evolution 
is not useful because it is "just" a theory -- it is useful because it *is* 
a scientific theory, as in the theory of gravity. If it was not a theory 
with powerful implications, why would, for instance, an estimated 47 of the 
last 50 Nobel Prizes in medicine have "crucially" depended on evolutionary 
theory in order to produce vaccines, anti-cancer treatment, etc? 
(reference: "Evolution is a Winner - for Breakthroughs and Prizes") Let's 
use a gut check: would the most-respected, brilliant medical researchers in 
the world rely on an unproven fantasy when billions of lives depend on the 
outcome, or would they use a well-supported theory?

Are all scientific theories of equal reliability? Are all theories bad 
because some theories are flawed? I do not think they are. Are theories on 
climate change are as rigorous as, say, the theory of evolution? What 
percentage of climate researchers consider humans to be the cause of global 
warming? Between 82-98% (ref: "Climate science opinion2.png") When the 
Discovery Institute tried to find scientists who disagreed with the theory 
of evolution, how many scientists in the world did they find, and how many 
of those are biologists? Less than 800, and about 1/4. (ref: "Few 
Biologists But Many Evangelicals Sign Anti-Evolution Petition") What 
percentage of all scientists support the theory of evolution? 99.9%+ (ref: 
"level of support for evolution") If academics are essentially unanimous on 
evolution, they are even more unanimous on thermodynamics: "If someone 
points out to you that your pet theory of the universe is in disagreement 
with Maxwell's equations — then so much the worse for Maxwell's equations. 
If it is found to be contradicted by observation — well, these 
experimentalists do bungle things sometimes. But if your theory is found to 
be against the second law of thermodynamics I can give you no hope; there 
is nothing for it but to collapse in deepest humiliation." (Arthur Stanley 
Eddington)

Test of common descent: if species A was the ancient ancestor of both B and 
C, will you find either fossilized B or C in the same period as A? Not one 
fossil of any mammal has ever been found in the precambrian period. In 
genetics: if modern Europeans, Middle Easterners and East Asians all 
descended from Africans, would their DNA be closer to that of modern 
Africans or that of ancient hominids of their respective regions, such as 
local Homo erectus? (See "Recent African origin of modern humans") Is there 
evidence for a universal common ancestor, as Darwin proposed, or are 
multiple separate ancestors more likely? Recent quantitative analysis on 
amino acid sequences across all major divisions of life have revealed that 
a single common ancestor fits much better with data (ref: "The Proof Is in 
the Proteins: Test Supports Universal Common Ancestor for All Life") What 
objective evidence exists for uncommon descent?

Test of abiogenesis: have you checked out the famous Miller-Urey experiment 
conducted in 1953? It used water, methane, ammonia, and hydrogen to 
simulate the early earth environment, with sparks from electrodes used to 
simulate lightning. If abiogenesis is impossible, why would the experiment 
produce many amino acids, the organic building blocks of life?

Test of macroevolution: macroevolution refers to evolution of entire groups 
of species at the level of the tree of life, such as how all the beetles 
evolved, tests of which require genetics, a technical topic. Speciation is 
the rise of new species. Are you looking for evidence on speciation? Did 
you take a look at "Observed Instances of Speciation"? What do you think 
about de Vries' finding in 1905 that some of his evening primrose had 
mutated and doubled in the number of chromosomes? These new plants could no 
longer reproduce with the original plants, becoming a new species with its 
own name, Oenothera gigas. Another example is the fruit fly Drosophila 
melanogaster: by using a maze to separate flies into different habitats, 
biologists bred the flies that prefered dry sections with flies that also 
prefered the dry section, and so on for flies that prefered the wet 
section. After 35 generations, the two groups of offspring became so 
different that they no longer reproduced with each other, even when that 
was their only chance of reproducing. This is speciation on a scale of a 
couple species. If you're looking for evidence of evolution with large 
physical differences, you can look at fossil records that span millions of 
years, showing various transitional forms (see "List of transitional 
fossils"). If you insist on producing "dinosaurs to birds" in a lab, I do 
not know how one can show that because that is not a scale of change 
researchers work with, but who knows, maybe someone will be able to speed 
up the process and show us in the future? For evidence of human 
transitional fossils, look at "List of human evolution fossils". Some 
species have had many fossil sites, including Homo erectus, Homo ergaster, 
Homo habilis, Homo heidelbergensis, and neanderthals. If you look at Homo 
habilis which died out over a million years ago, their brain capacity is 
half of human's, consistent with the idea that brain capacity in hominids 
is increasing. In 2013, scientists sequenced the entire DNA of a 
neanderthal from Siberia, exracted from its toe bone. We are at least 94% 
the same as chimpanzees and more than 99% the same as neanderthals; these 
are experimental results, not hypotheses.

Test of global warming: we could get every country to produce tons of 
greenhouse gases. If we do that and the average global temperature keeps 
dropping or doesn't rise, then the idea would be obviously wrong. But time 
is irreversible. If the temperature did keep rising, could it cause some 
issues down the road? You may disagree with them, but you can probably 
understand why some would not want to risk waiting until it's too late. We 
are entitled to our opinions. Mine is that there are more interesting 
scientific theories to talk about than climate change models, though I see 
no reason why governments should not err on the side of caution when it 
comes to protecting the environment of which I am a part.

Scientific theories are not dogma. If there is public knowledge that a 
theory has been violated, but a scientist refuses to absorb new evidence 
and produce new theory, then they are not really protecting their own 
legacy, because a community of countless independent members have no 
incentive to lag behind for the sake of one individual. If someone presents 
convincing evidence that Dawkins is wrong, what chance would he have of 
suppressing that information? Could he prevent the publication of the 
information in all journals? Even if established scientists try to advocate 
an inferior theory, why would rising scientists base their future career on 
it, when they can produce better predictions with another theory? Of course 
anyone can become disappointed when their theory becames outdated, but that 
is a personal matter, and science is not about any one person or central 
authority.

Skepticism: if a person is naturally skeptical in general, wouldn't he or 
she also remain skeptical of supernatural concepts such as God? Is evidence 
of the supernatural or spiritual world necessarily more convincing than 
evidence of the material world? If you consider one of them far fetched on 
the basis of skepticism, would it also be reasonable to consider the other 
one equally far fetched, if not more so? Thomas Jefferson for instance 
wrote his own version of the Bible which excluded miracles and supernatural 
events, yet focused on the moral message of Jesus. Jefferson eventually 
called himself a "materialist". Which is more beneficial for society, 
talking about the nature of demons and angels, or talking about the nature 
of morality?
comments.author: anon

comments.text:
+iCookie1

You do understand that "facts" are observations right? If we can see 
speciation happening (which has been seen and documented several times) 
then this is called as a "fact". Evolution is basically descent with 
modification - you are not genetically identical to your parents and you 
descended from them. This is evolution. Your argument is against what you 
call "macroevolution" which is changes of the order genus - these happen on 
geological timescales and are inferred from observations of fossil records 
and DNA. These observations are also "facts".

The theory attempts to explain these observations and the mechanisms by 
which they occur - natural selection, random mutations and horizontal gene 
transfer. Abiogenesis is a hypothesis and most likely we will never know 
how life actually started.

Also remember that science is not about proofs - it's about evidence. 
Proofs only exist in mathematics and logic - science can never prove 
anything. You also seem to think that only atheists accept evolution - this 
is not the case. The only thing ALL atheists have in common is a lack of 
belief in deities - that's all. The Catholic Church accepts evolution - 
they are not atheists. Most Buddhists probably don't give a shit about 
evolution - and there are hundreds of millions of them, mostly atheist.

fundamental level, I am asking, "why should I believe in hell?" and you are 
asking, "why shouldn't I believe in hell?" But you are asking the wrong 
question. For instance, why shouldn't you believe in Islam? the spaghetti 
monster? Hinduism? Buddism? A giant purple elephant in the sky that can

is, if you ask the question, "Why shouldn't I believe in 'X'," then you 
will end up believing in EVERYTHING except for the things that can be 
distinctly proven false. I used to believe in santa clause for the same 
reason, however as Mr. Dawkins says, "When we grow up we tend to forget 
childish things." It is basic scientific method and logic to assume nothing 
exists until we can provide evidence that it does. Not the other way around.

comments.text:
At some point the things we discover in science will, and already are, 
refuting things discussed in the bible, and other holy books. For instance, 
the earth being the center of the universe, or the age of the earth, or 
snakes talking. (thats an old one :p) Cosmos should be casting the bible as 
an error... cause guess what? IT IS! This is being shown again and again as 
we learn more about the true world around us. Cosmos 2 did not directly 
attack any religion, although it has on many occasions brought up the 
concepts of evolution and stated them as facts. (which they are.) And yes, 
religion does hinder science in some ways, if barely. for example look at 
newton's laws of gravity-- while he was working on this concept he stated 
that he could describe the motion of the planets, but it was not worth his 
time to try and explain where the planets themselves came from, because god 
is too mysterious. (this is a paraphrase obviously.) Now clearly religion 
is NOT tied to intelligence, and many great scientists were religious, like 
newton himself. However at some point science and religion begin to clash, 
and that has been happening ever since people started seriously considering 
the age of the earth, and where we came from via evolution. You'll have to 
start picking up on some of the modern explanations my friend, as with 
every generation more and more people do. (30% of U.S. teenagers are 
athiest/agnostic VS 12% total U.S. residents.)
