comments.text:
First of all, please don't use ad hominems and personal attacks.
I'm not a moral relativist, I am a moral absolutist. Maybe you should read 
a bit on secular morality.
Believing that everything is just an interaction of particles does not take 
away my freedom to choose. The reason is because those particle 
interactions that make up my identity *are* my identity. The particle 
interactions outside of my identity may change my identity, but they will 
not change my choices directly. Of course, this flies directly against your 
idea of soul, but people change based on their life experiences. Obviously 
a different person chooses differently. This does not mean the person is 
not free, but that the very core that chooses is subject to external 
influence. I do not control who *I* are (is), But *I* choose (chooses). 
This idea can be difficult to grasp, but it solves the whole determinism vs 
free will debate.
Yes, I am comfortable with the notion that given an infinite amount of time 
there is nothing too complex to be formed simply by chance. This very 
comment could be reproduced by a machine that types random keys given 
enough time. But I do question the existence of infinite time in our 
universe.
In a universe without a god, the absence of a god is an absolute truth, 
thus a universe without a god is not a place where absolute truth does not 
exist.
Finally, stating that God is eternal and omnipresent is not the same as 
argumenting why God is omnipresent and eternal.
My argument is that God could not have existed before time because the very 
definition of existence requires the time dimension. Something cannot exist 
for 0 seconds.
So far your only response to that is to simply state that God is eternal 
and omnipresent. Please provide a valid argument to support your position.

comments.text:
+TheGateKeeper "Teach facts not the interpretation of facts."

Herein lies your fallacy.  What constitutes a fact?  Is gravity a fact to 
you, for example?  I'm curious about your definition of fact.

Strictly speaking, science does not deal with facts.  To science, gravity 
is tantamount to being a fact, i.e., a theory, because it has been tested, 
retested, and built upon.  It is generally assumed as fact.

Likewise, the process of evolution is a theory.  Most people mistakenly 
define (and use causally) the word theory as a synonym of hypothesis.  "I 
had a theory about that..."  No.  A theory is a accepted, workable body of 
evidence, again tantamount but not considered a fact.  Science doesn't deal 
with facts because to do so would be folly – scientists don't come to a 
conclusion, call it a fact, and say, "That's that."  Everything is suspect.

Do we know everything about the evolution of life on earth over the past 4 
billion years?  Absolutely not.  But, we can continue to test and retest 
the theory, each new piece of evidence teaching us something new or 
corroborating our predictions.

Finally, I cannot subscribe to your dogma that DNA = designer = DNA = 
designer.  There are minerals.  There are inert gasses.  There are 
compounds.  None of these are proof of a designer.  DNA is a happenstance 
outcome of complex proteins stringing themselves together, reacting and 
interacting with the chemicals of the world around them.

In a nutshell, that's all life is about, and all we do, too.
comments.author: Chad-Michael Simon

wanted to purposefully craft every breed of dog, in a few centuries 
creating breeds as diverse as Shih Tzus and Great Danes.  That was before 
we understood genetics.  Now that we understand the system behind it, the 
number of mixes has exploded.

time.  Literal creationists who believe the Earth is 6,000 years old

time, the time it's taken for single-celled organisms to develop into the 
diversity of life that exists now.  It's trackable, repeatable, testable,

would denounce this body of evidence.

comments.text:
+chrismay1a WHY THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS A GOOD ATHEIST

(Read all of it, let's see if you can be objective and expressive with 
logical conclusions of factual observation and reasoning.)

While it is true that there is no definitive atheistic worldview, all 
atheists share the same fundamental beliefs as core to their personal 
worldviews. While some want to state that atheism is simply a disbelief in 
the existence of a god, there really is more to it. Every expression of 
atheism necessitates at least three additional affirmations:

1. The universe is purely material. It is strictly natural, and there is no 
such thing as the supernatural (e.g., gods or spiritual forces).
2. The universe is scientific. It is observable, knowable and governed 
strictly by the laws of physics.
3. The universe is impersonal. It does not a have consciousness or a will, 
nor is it guided by a consciousness or a will.

Denial of any one of those three affirmations will strike a mortal blow to 
atheism. Anything and everything that happens in such a universe is 
meaningless. A tree falls. A young girl is rescued from sexual slavery. A 
dog barks. A man is killed for not espousing the national religion. These 
are all actions that can be known and explained but never given any meaning 
or value.
A good atheist -- that is, a consistent atheist -- recognizes this dilemma. 
His only reasonable conclusion is to reject objective meaning and morality. 
Thus, calling him "good" in the moral sense is nonsensical. There is no 
morally good atheist, because there really is no objective morality. At 
best, morality is the mass delusion shared by humanity, protecting us from 
the cold sting of despair.
For those of you who think you're about to light up this supposed straw man 
and raze me to the ground, consider the following:
"Modern science directly implies that there ... is no ultimate meaning for 
humans."
--William Provine
"The universe we observe has precisely the properties we should expect if 
there is, at bottom, no design, no purpose, no evil and no good, nothing 
but blind, pitiless indifference. ... DNA neither knows nor cares. DNA just 
is. And we dance to its music."
--Richard Dawkins
"No species, ours included, possesses a purpose beyond the imperatives 
created by its genetic history."
--Edward O. Wilson
Based on the nonnegotiable premises of atheism, these are the only logical 
conclusions. But I've never met an atheist who's managed to live this way. 
All the atheists I've known personally and from afar live as if there is 
objective meaning and morality. How is this explained? In a Hail Mary-like 
attempt to reconcile the inescapability of objective morality and their 
assurances of atheism, two possible answers are launched.

1. Morality is the result of socio-biological evolution. This is a 
two-pronged attempt at justifying moral claims. First, a sense of morality 
evolved to ensure human survival. Much like an eye or tooth, it is 
necessary for the human race to continue. If this were true, for any claim 
to be moral, it would have to serve the practical purpose of advancing the 
human race. So compassion for the dying would be immoral, and killing 
mentally handicapped children would be moral. Perhaps the most moral action 
would be men raping many women and forcing them to birth more children.
Morality, in this view, can only mean those actions that are helpful to 
make more fit humans. It does nothing to help us grapple with the truth 
that it's always wrong to torture diseased children or rape women.
Second, morality was developed to ensure the success of societies, which 
are necessary for human survival and thriving. Like the rules of a board 
game, morality is contrived to bring us together for productivity and 
happiness. If this were true, there is nothing to which we can appeal when 
we find the behavior of other societies repugnant and reprehensible. 
Because morality is the construct of a social group, it cannot extend 
further than a society's borders or endure longer than a society's 
existence.
Furthermore, within our own society, the most immoral are not merely the 
ones who transgress our code but the ones who intend to change it. This 
would make those fighting for marriage equality the most immoral -- that 
is, until they become the majority and institute change. I suppose they 
then become moral, and traditionalists become immoral. But it's the math 
that determines rightness or wrongness of a side, not the content of any 
belief or argument.
So this view of morality does nothing to provide a reasonable answer for 
why it would be objectively wrong to torture diseased children, rape women 
or kill those who don't affirm a national religion. It only provides a 
motivation for continuing the delusion of objective morality.

2. Morality is logical. Atheists who take this route start in a position of 
checkmate without realizing it. First, the temptation is to pervert this 
conversation into a debate about whether atheists can be moral. Of course 
they can. That is not the question. The question is how we make sense of 
moral claims if we play by the rules that atheism demands.
Morality may be logical, but logic does not equate to morality. The only 
way to make a logical moral argument is to presuppose morality and meaning 
to start with. Try making a logical argument that slavery is wrong without 
presupposing morality. It is impossible. A woman wrote to me with her 
attempt at doing just that. Her claim was that slavery is logically wrong 
because it diminishes other human beings. The problem is that that argument 
presupposes human dignity. In the strict framework of atheism outlined 
above, what reason is there to ever assume human dignity?
All logical arguments for morality assume that human thriving, happiness 
and dignity are superior to contrary views. The strict framework of atheism 
does not allow for those starting points. So any person arguing for 1 or 2 
would not be a good atheist. That is, he lives in contradiction to the 
mandates of his worldview.

Conclusion
Intelligent people ask serious questions. Serious questions deserve serious 
answers. There are few questions more serious than the one I'm asking. How 
do we explain objective meaning and morality that we know are true? If a 
worldview can't answer this question, it doesn't deserve you.
One sign that your worldview may be a crutch is that it has to appeal to an 
answer outside itself -- becoming self-contradictory, unable to reasonably 
account for the question. Any atheist who recognizes objective meaning and 
morality defies the atheism that he contends is true.
If your worldview can't makes sense of the things that make most sense to 
you (like objective morality), then it's not worth your allegiance. This 
new reality may launch you onto a journey of reluctant discovery. Whoever 
you are. Wherever you are. Whatever you believe. You deserve a foundation 
that is strong enough to carry the values that carry you.
comments.author: ICH LIEBE DEUTSCHLAND

design both sound illogical. So reject them both and take a neutral stance.

accept any model of reality unless it is well supported with actual facts

+TheGateKeeper First off, sufficiently addressing your assertions cannot be 
done in a single short post.

1) You said rapid FOSSILIZATION before, not rapid burial. Rapid burial is 
not a prerequisite either, though it certainly helps. Calcium carbonate 
(chalk), for example, is made up of fossils of microscopic marine organisms 
(coccolithophores) which are not rapidly buried and build up over VERY long 
periods of time. There are layers of chalk hundreds of feet thick (the 
White Cliffs of Dover in England) which COULD NOT HAPPEN if the earth were 
less than 10,000 years old.

2a) What do you mean by "fully developed"? Do you think evolution predicts 
organisms with only half a body? The Cambrian "explosion" occurred over 
approximately a 50-80 million year period around 550 million years ago! Do 
you really think it helps your case for young earth creationism?? It was a 
RELATIVELY rapid period of complex development.

2b) You're just copying and pasting from a creationist website, apparently 
Creation MINISTRIES (yeah, that's scientific) or one of the many religious 
sites that copied from it. The creationist author of your article proceeds 
to dishonestly quote mine and twist the Scientific American article by 
Levinton.    Levinton NEVER said in that article that "no new or different 
body plans appeared after the Cambrian". Here's what Levinton actually said 
right in his first paragraph:
      "FEW new major body plans have appeared since that time. Just as all 
automobiles are fundamentally modeled after the first four-wheel vehicles, 
all the evolutionary changes since the Cambrian period have been mere 
variations on these basic themes."

He goes on to say:
       "The progenitors of the distinct animal groups found in the Cambrian 
could conceivably have diverged hundreds of millions of years earlier, yet 
they might not have left fossils because they lacked shells or skeletons. 
If so, the Cambrian diversification might not have been as explosive as is 
generally assumed."

I highly recommend you read the full Levinton article in Scientific 
American Nov 1992 and see for yourself all the information your creationist 
source conveniently left out.
 
2c) Notice how the creationist article you're referencing doesn't cite any 
creationist research in scientific journals. There's a reason for that. 
Creationists cannot present ANY research, experimentation or independently 
verifiable observation demonstrating their religious (not scientific) idea 
of magical special creation. All they continue to do is throw stones at the 
vast amount of scientific research that deals with biological evolution and 
hope religious audiences (who are used to believing on faith what they are 
told to) believe as they're told without checking for themselves.

2d) Its not my job to hunt for evidence to support your argument. Its your 
job to find that evidence and present it. Its also a good idea to learn 
about the subject you're dealing with from the most knowledgeable sources 
on that subject, i.e the worldwide scientific community and the research 
they've produced. You wouldn't go to a hairdresser to learn about 
engineering and likewise, you shouldn't be going to theologians to learn 
about biology.

3a) You disagree that DNA is naturally occurring? The "everything else" 
you're referring to are SPECIFICALLY MAN MADE THINGS. We know things such 
as buildings, cars, painting etc. are "creations" because they do not occur 
naturally and we can examine the processes by which humans create them. Do 
these characteristics apply to the things you believe a god created? Can we 
examine the process by which this god created things? Can we even examine 
the creator itself in order to determine what it can create or has created? 
No, we can't. You're simply assuming this creator exists and it created 
everything because an ancient primitive culture says so.

Also, you didn't answer my question...how do you distinguish between the 
artificial and the natural if you believe EVERYTHING is intentionally 
created? What would something natural look like?

3b) Neither I nor science has ever said the natural world COULDN'T have a 
"Creator/Designer"....I'm simply asking for the evidence that supports your 
argument that it does have a creator. Everything we've examined within the 
universe thus far and found a cause for is explained by natural mechanisms 
with no mysterious magical "creator" necessary to explain it. Even if you 
could demonstrate that everything was created/designed, how do you reliably 
determine what created/designed it? Will you just assume that the 
particular creator you believe in is the one who did it? Maybe something 
completely different made it all. You're beginning with a preferred 
conclusion instead of following the evidence where it leads.

3c) Unlike religion, science does not insist you believe the information it 
presents "because they say so". Instead, science presents the data and 
methodology used to reach these conclusions and invites (as a necessity) 
anyone to test for themselves. Once again, faith and unquestioning 
authority are the purview of religion, not science.

4a) You and other creationists always attempt to paint "evolutionists" as 
some fringe group separate from the scientific community...yet the 
overwhelming majority of the worldwide scientific community accepts 
evolution (even higher percentage of biologists). Creationism is the fringe 
group with only a relatively tiny handful of scientists rejecting evolution 
on purely religious grounds.

4b) What "ridiculous uniformatarian assumptions" do you think scientific 
dating methods are based on? Atomic decay is ridiculous to you? Can you

religious sources about science.

Yes, I mentioned that as a consequence of competition with the USSR.

*"We also created nuclear energy."*
This is not to necessarily diminish the achievement, but taking all the 
credit for creating it is quite a stretch. We did not singularly discover 
the principles and processes of it, but we did power four light bulbs with 
it first. WW2 and the Cold War managed to be quite a motivating spur.

*"So our religions did not stop those things, anymore than communism 
stopped the first human going into space."*

the USSR, there was no scientific achievement of advancement) while you did 
not intend it as such. Sorry, if that's the case.

To be clear on my perspective here, I don't think religion is always an 
obstruction to progress and advancement, but I do think that sometimes it 
is. I will admit that the degree to which it may impede or has impeded any 
given individual is debatable. In cases where it has become over-zealous 
conservative (sometimes even regressive) idealism (whether that's in terms 
of the commonly accepted concepts of religion, or in examples such as 
Nazism or Stalinism), I think it ultimately makes itself a greatly 
detrimental hindrance. And that point is where I agree with the OP of this 
thread.

As to your other point, that there are some nutjobs on all sides is not 
news to me. There are plenty of cases such as this where I may disagree on 
certain points with people who I may agree with on other points. I think 
that the right to disagree with ideas about global warming should be 
guaranteed. The right for the people who do so to be taken seriously, 
however, is not guaranteed and should not be.

comments.text:
+paulczar Excellent; well said, Paul. Let me toss something out at you 
-- you've made a very good case for dumping religion; so if we're willing 
to lose the whole thing anyway, what's stopping us from taking what's 
beneficial to us and leaving what's not?

"The Word of God" indeed. Rather than thinking this to mean "This book is 
written by God and is therefore literal and perfect" let's look at an 
alternative example...

Maybe I think "God" is the conglomerate consciousness of all things in the 
entire universe, from which we all have originated and remain a part of in 
this moment. This pure, perfect, whole, utter well-beingness is our true 
nature and is the state that we return to after death. What is the 
perspective of this "higher self?" What does it have to say about this 
world and our relationship to it? Well, we have here the "Word of God," and 
we may use it as a fulcrum to leverage ourselves into alignment with that 
of our true nature, AKA "God."

*Mark **12:17**, Jesus said unto them, "Render to Caesar the things that 
are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”*  Yes, the physical 
world must have its due; your hair must be combed, you car fueled, your 
atoms smashed and examined -- some attention on worldly matters is 
appropriate.

But we have said that there is something more than just the physical, and 
it must have its little attentions too. This sentiment includes the idea of 
the Sabbath day, where one might give due attention to that deeper, higher 
part of oneself. What things are God's, that we should render unto "him?" 

Well, we can render our *attention* on being spiritually resourceful, and 
tapping into the power of God/self whenever it suits us. Centering 
yourself, calming down and breathing deeply for a few long minutes before 
making important decisions or starting important conversations -- or maybe 
doing it just because it feels good to remind yourself who you truly are. 
We can render our *permission* for this power to play an influential role 
in our lives.

This interpretation is beneficial to the person who holds the belief that 
we began with, but you might find other meanings that speak to you from 
your own perspective. I believe that in this way your deeper self  may 
communicate with you through your personal interpretation of the a passage.

Here's something almost entirely overlooked: *we all may have different 
interpretations and spiritual standards that benefit us most;* ones 
that play into our unique perspective, rather than forcing a square peg 
into a round hole. All spokes point toward the hub, and many 
interpretations may point toward the same truth.

So what if we play fast-and-loose with the scriptures? Take the good and 
leave the bad, according to our own personal judgment -- never mind 
what anyone (no matter how fancily dressed) tells us it's supposed to 
mean. And how will you know  when you've struck on the "right" 
interpretation? Because the one that is right for you (in that moment, at 
least) will resonate with you on a deep level; it will feel profound 
and change your perspective.

"So who dictates what is to be taken literally and what is to be viewed as 
more of a metaphor?" It's our lives, it's our minds -- *we do.* This seems 
to be a course of action quite befitting a fully conscious, self-reliant 
being. What do you think?
comments.author: Brian Blackwell

you, my friend, are a champion of the future. We *must* begin to encourage 
a metaphorical/abstract interpretation of the Bible. When you study 
religious texts throughout the world, patterns emerge that are undeniable, 
and recognition of patterns equals understanding. Virgin births, 
resurrections, bodily flights to the afterlife, etc., etc., are present in 
many traditions. 

Once you see this, you can begin to look at what these stories mean, what 
they point to. There are so many lessons in the religious texts that are 
lost amidst a literal interpretation.  All the spokes of a wheel point 
toward the center, and all spiritual traditions can tell us *something* 
about the one universal truth.

theory itself. Other fields provide sets of data as well.  Archaeology 
requires cross-disciplinary research so many theories are not developed by 
archaeologist themselves but are incorporated in an individual's findings. 
Biology, zoology, anthropology, etc. So without this research from other 
fields archaeology can say nothing about human evolution. 

 
This is not coming from an atheist but from a person with a B/A in 
archaeology in the graduate program, Ph. D. I think I know what my own 
career studies...

evidenced as TRUE. This includes the assertion "god did it"

comments.text:
+Cole Skeptic Lacks >>There are not laws without a lawgiver, but how does 
this lawgiver look? <<

Partisans of String Theory could answer that one with their own godless 
version. What I mean by that is that by "lawgiver", we can't be sure he 
meant a sapient one (sentient, intelligent, whatever), or even a 
supernatural one. If you heard me going on one of my spiritual-ish rampage 
about the beauty of physics, you could think I'm talking about a 
supernatural something, while I'm a firm atheist (or you could think I'm 
slightly out there, and you'd probably be right :p).

Truth is, Einstein strikes me as someone who just didn't want to be labeled 
and put in a neat box re: his beliefs or lack thereof. He might have 
disliked atheists because he thought them aspiritual (is that even a word?) 
and over materialistic. I don't know. I might be wrong. :)

Bottom line is, what Einstein believed is irrelevant to his contribution 
(as long as it doesn't get in the way of his own work), and him being 
Einstein doesn't validate or invalidate his kind of belief in any way. My 
profound admiration for him as a scientist and a humanist isn't going to 
change my stance on religion, the same way I won't suddenly become 
christian because Newton was, or polytheist because of Thales.
comments.author: Virginia I

comments.text:
Sorry, I mean, you can interpret it however you would like, but even though 
Einstein did not have a personal god, he stated many times in his life that 
he had a belief that the universe had a grand supernatural creator. 
He also very much disliked the idea of atheists and many times asked to be 
kept separate from them. 
He said in an interview "God is a mystery. But a comprehensible mystery. I 
have nothing but awe when I observe the laws of nature. There are not laws 
without a lawgiver, but how does this lawgiver look? Certainly not like a 
man magnified."
He clearly believed in some supernatural god, though it was no theist 
personal god.
comments.author: Cole Skeptic Lacks

comments.text:
+Cole Skeptic Lacks 

"It was, of course, a lie what you read about my religious convictions, a 
lie which is being systematically repeated. *I do not believe in a personal 
God* and I have never denied this but have expressed it clearly. If 
something is in me which can be called religious then it is the unbounded 
admiration for the structure of the world so far as our science can reveal 
it." 

- Albert Einstein, letter to an atheist (1954)

(emphasis mine)

To Einstein, "religion" means "spirituality" - a concept that doesn't need 
a specific belief or non-belief to exist - which he defines as "the 
unbounded admiration for the structure of the world so far as our science 
can reveal it".

Which of course has nothing to do with the validity of his work, his 
contribution to general physics, or whether or not God exists. As far as 
I'm concerned, he could have worshipped Nyarlathotep, E=MC² would still be 
a beautiful thing.

comments.text:
I respect your views and am not trying to change it. If I rely on my own 
means to change you mind, I might fail, because I am just another human 
being.  I appreciate the fact that we could share ideas without acting 
stupid or insulting, as I see other users do. I don't understand why people 
think they would even earn respect by insulting other people who have 
difference of opinion. We know that Paul was a Roman citizen, so he might 
have had to be careful of what he wrote (like his letters that could get 
him into trouble with the Roman authorities, would they have offended the 
government of the day). That is part of the context that I believe that the 
readers need to understand. If Mark and John wrote different versions of 
events, that is why there are four gospels to begin with. Editing them and 
changing them so that they seem less contradictory would be unscientific 
and dishonest. Even the court today acknowledge that witnesses give 
different recounts of events, because we are dealing with people here. The 
court then has to decide which common evidence is accepted beyond 
reasonable doubt.

What I am trying to do is not to insult your intelligence, only try to help 
you understand the way I think. I actually agree with you that faith 
doesn't always make sense. But then again, why does science make sense? Who 
decided that 3 comes after 2 and before 4? Who decided that when you write 
a sequence of symbols that it would become a message that both of us can 
understand? And why can't I understand all the languages of the world? We 
learn this and we believe it. If you are going to show me a Japanese symbol 
for boat I won't believe that it means boat until someone tells me that 
it's a boat. And such a "someone" can make up any lies and I would have to 
believe it, since I am not an expert on Japanese.

No matter what you believe, I hope you will be happy and find comfort in 
whatever you believe in or don't. :-)
comments.author: Morne Van der Berg

comments.text:
+Morne Van der Berg First off, thanks for the reply and I apologize for 
having been overly sarcastic and antagonistic. I made the same erroneous 
assumption you did :)

There's a lot I agree with your post, especially the notions of legacy and 
esp. context, which I find extremely important when dealing with the bible 
(or any ancient text). People (on both sides) tend to forget it was written 
in very different times and places, and what seem ludicrous for us, such as 
the "no shrimps" clause, actually made sense and was vital advice there and 
then (bad seafood can kill you). From my atheist pov, if the wise men of 
the times needed to invoke a supreme authority (God) and punishment to get 
basic hygiene and social rules through their contemporaries' thick skull, 
then so be it. It's a well-known parenting trick, after all.

By contradictions, I didn't mean OT vs. NT, but more both factual 
contradictions and ideological / moral ones. Sticking to the OT, I can't 
reconcile "You shall not kill" with the endless string of massacres not 
only condoned but ordered by God, to take the most obvious example. As for 
the NT, it would be just fine as both a moral guideline and a historical 
account (partially - transmutation, among other things, remains a bit 
far-fetched) if Paul didn't feel the need to meddle after the fact and 
spread his vitriol and intolerance all over it.

And there's very little things such as Jesus dying in three hours in Marc 
and  six in John. Trivial little details, but when you're supposed to 
consider the scriptures as the Truth, a scientific mind can't help but 
question the whole thing from there (and I realize it can be argued that 
they don't in fact contradict each others, and that's a matter of 
interpretation etc... but if you need that level of explanation to justify 
that very simple thing, then there's a problem).
comments.author: Virginia I

comments.text:
+Virginia I since we are quoting Google now, lol 
http://carm.org/why-apocrypha-not-in-bible ... to be honest, a person with 
a Catholic background might not understand thy I say the apocrypha is not 
part of the Bible, since it was actually a long list of catholic popes who 
insisted these apocrypha be somehow included in the Bible. It might be part 
of the Douay Rheims Bible, but NOT the King James version. When I refer to 
the Bible, I refer to the KJV. I just pointed out psalm 118:8 as an example 
of the structure that the Bible has - and I do find it interesting that the 
middle chapter of the Bible is after the shortest chapter and before the 
longest chapter, But even though I do not agree with everything you say, I 
respect that you have different views. We have different views, since we 
have had different experiences.But this is what it all boils down to: Some 
of us choose to believe in some things that others don't, even though 
belief is something that is based on the unseen. Now we might change what 
we believe in when we allow circumstances to change our resilience of 
faith, but we still choose to believe. If it seems that all my comments 
were directed just at you, I apologize (only if the shoe fits too often), 
but really, you did mention elements from Enoch that suggested that it's 
more like a fairy tale and then used it as an example of a book in the 
Bible to illustrate that the Bible is also as such, where that notion, in 
fact challenges what many believe in. If I keep quiet and do not challenge 
this in return, then what is the point in having faith at all? And about 
the contradictions: The only reason why people find parts of the Bible 
contradictory, is that they put verses together and out of context. Every 
story has its context and should be seen in the time and place where it is 
intended to be. Matthew 5:38 is a good example. - you might say that this 
contradicts what Exodus 21:24, Leviticus 24:20 and Deuteronomy 19:21 says. 
Well, it does, because the speaker in Matthew 5 is Jesus and he is teaching 
the people about the new covenant. The two hales of the Bible seem 
contradictory, yes, since the old and new testaments describes two eras, 
before Christ and after Christ. Christ brought a new covenant. So why is 
the old testament relevant then? to show the limits of man- even from the 
starting point at Genesis. Then, eventually the prophets predict that there 
would be a Saviour, a change, a difference - not wrath, but mercy. I will 
always have respect for people with faith and the Bible, since I understand 
its context. Some maturity is required to look at the Bible sensibly. We 
are evolving as a human race- changing our understanding. Look at how much 
we learned in the last 200 years, or even in the last 2000. Yes, people 
took religion to far in the middle ages, not knowing what viruses are, 
thinking that illness and dying is a direct result of sin. Now we know that 
viruses can be deadly, yes, but we can use antibiotics to cure the 
symptoms. Only 200 years ago, if we had spoken about evolution in the way 
we do today, the Roman Catholic Church would have us burnt as heretics just 
for the fact that we believe something that seems to contradict creation as 
it has been described in the Bible. So, should we look down at our 
forefathers? No, we should respect everyone who has toiled to bring us to 
this point where we can freely debate the issue at hand. To me, that does 
not make the Bible irrelevant, as long as we understand the context 
thereof. I mean, the authors of the Bible did not even know that the earth 
was round, did they? So how could we expect an accurate description of 
earth anywhere in the Bible. But I still marvel at creation, no matter how 
differently I look at it than the Biblical authors did. So much of it is 
still relevant, as long as you understand the times and the people who 
created the text

+Utwig
'Jesus Christ' is not a title.  'Jesus' is a name, and 'Christ' is a title, 
just like 'Obama' is a name and 'President' is a title.  'Christ' is the 
anglicization of a Greek word meaning 'anointed one', just as 'messiah' is 
an anglicization of a Hebrew word with the same meaning.  'Christ' is not a 
name; Jesus Christ was not the son of Joseph an Mary Christ.

'Christ Jesus'.  If anything is backwards, it is 'Jesus Christ'.  Likewise, 
would you say 'President Obama' or  'Obama President'?

comments.text:
+truebinx Fair enough; that's a personal choice and it seems you've thought 
it through well enough. A big part of the problem is that religious leaders 
insist on presenting the faith as an all-or-none proposition by asserting 
the literal truth of the entirity of religious scripture. Until we can 
somehow resolve the issue of having *any* scriptural information being 
refuted necessarily implying that it's all of no use, we can't get anywhere.

When you assert that creationism is wrong, people have no choice but to 
disagree or lose their faith in its entirity (if they want to be in keeping 
with the religion as a whole). Even an atheist must understand that this is 
asking a lot, as change is usually a more gradual process. They feel like 
they *must* choose a side.

I believe a shift toward a more metaphorical interpretation of scripture 
must occur for the major faiths to survive. Until then, I'll just teach my 
child to think critically and to differenciate between humanity's enormous 
library of lore, and it's meager handful of "knowledge.﻿"
comments.author: Brian Blackwell

responsible) to bear the burdens of the world on our very narrow 
shoulders." That burden becomes a lot easier to bear with multiple

carefully". I don't worry about how what to do about the deteriorating 
relationship with the US and Russia, or how to cure cancer, or how to end 
the famines in Africa. I don't have the know how to do that. But I take 
comfort in knowing that someone much more capable than I is on the job. But 
I will fight the battles I can influence and make even the slightest 
difference. I do think that Creationism is worth the fight, it promotes 
flawed logic and hinders critical thinking at it's most basic levels, it's 
because we shed these types of superstitions that we are able to argue with 
each other from different parts of the globe on the internet.
comments.author: truebinx

comments.text:
+truebinx I understand where you're coming from; I don't prefer that they 
teach creationism either, but there's so much more to it than that.

We've been duped into believing that it's appropriate (morally/socially 
responsible) to bear the burdens of the world on our very narrow shoulders. 
Worldwide media brings us problems from every corner of the globe to 
consider every day; and the human psyche simply cannot bear it. We're 
overburdened and overstressed, and on a frantic never-ending search for 
relief through material objects, ideologies, and trying to change people 
and the world to fit our preferred model.

There will never be enough money, enough truth, or enough conformity to 
ease the tension. We have to let go... and we have to let it be.

educational cirriculum? You prefer physical "evidence" and they prefer 
divine "revelation." Who's paradigm should reign supreme? On answering this 
question, everyone agrees; and the world replies in resounding chorus -- 
"mine!" 

On an indivulidual level we all know next to nothing about it anyway, 
having neither witnessed evidence or revelation first-hand; we're just 
buying into the story that seems most reasonable to us. We all know that 
people make up their own minds anyway, once they're old enough to do so, 
and until then they don't care anyway -- they're just regurgitating what 
they're told so the grown-ups dont bitch.

We have to cut through this illusion of grand importance surrounding all 
this inane minutia. What's life all about? Certainly not fiddling with all 
these little meaningless points of contention, or a futile attempt to gain 
worldwide consensus about our every thought and opinion; as this has been 
sufficiently proved impossible.

comments.text:
But he'll *do* exactly the opposite of the ^^^^^above^^^^^ little speech 
apparently, if the paycheck and the temporary and phony "rock star" 
adulation for science's latest "golden child" is big enough. Between the 
premiere episode, and the final installment which bookended the series, one 
thing's clear, that de Grasse Tyson is a master at speaking out of both 
sides of his mouth. Who else was it, other than de Grasse Tyson himself (at 
the obvious urging of at least MacFarlane, the most well-known and most 
outspoken of the executive producers of the show for his anti-religious 
rhetoric), who voiced the obviously overly harsh and long-winded *20-minute 
long* anti-religion harangue in the premiere episode? And who was it who 
tried to supposedly soften that bludgeoning by sprinkling in little 
3-second blurbs every once in a great while in ensuing episodes stating how 
*everyone*, even scientists, should be always questioning, but also 
"tolerant" of opposing viewpoints? de Grasse Tyson's apparently not going 
to waste the *cha-CHING!!!* possibilities of his "15 minutes", even if he 
has to get himself eyeballs-deep in double-speak in order to do it.
